Play details
The downfall of Robert, Earl of Huntington. Genre: History. Date first published: 1601. Date first performed: 1598? STC 18271

editorialDecl.p: The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Earl of Huntington/Robin Hood Maid Marion/Matilda Lord Chester Sir John Eltam Bishop of Ely Skelton Earl of Leicester Richmond Prior of York Little John Jinny Simon Earl of Leicester/Lord Salisbury(changes after line 781) Much/Clown Scarlet Lord Lacy/Lord Fitzwater Prince John Queen Elinor King Richard Justice Warman Friar Tuck Warman's Wife Widdow Scarlet Mistress Thomson Servant/Servingman Shrieve Watch Messenger Boy Ralph 1 Collier 2 Collier Sheriff Herald Cousin Jailer Combined speech Scathlock Sir Doncaster Sir Hugh Lacy within

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following.

body.stage: Main text Enter sir Iohn Eltam, and knocke at Skeltons doore.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.l: How, master Skelton? what, at study hard?

sp.speaker: Skelt.
sp.l: Welcome, and wished for, honest sir Iohn Eltam.
I have sent twice, and either time
he missed, that went to seek you.

sp.speaker: Elt.
sp.l: So full well he might.
These two hours it pleased his Majesty
To use my service in surveying Maps,
Sent over from the good king Ferdinand,
That to the Indies, at Sebastians suit,
Hath lately sent a Spanish Colony.

sp.speaker: Sk.
sp.l: Then it will trouble you, after your great affairs,
To take the pain that I intended to entreat you to,
About rehearsal of your promised play.

sp.speaker: Elt.
sp.l: Nay master Skelton: for the king himself,
As we were parting, bid me take great heed
We fail not of our day, therefore I pray
Send for the rest, that now we may rehearse.

sp.speaker: Skel.
sp.l: O they are ready all, and dressed to play.
What part play you?

sp.speaker: Elt.
sp.l: Why? I play little Iohn,
And came of purpose with this green suit.

sp.speaker: Skel.
sp.l: Holla my masters, little Iohn is come.

body.stage: At euery doore all the Players runne out, some crying where? where? others welcome sir Iohn, among other the boyes and Clowne.

sp.speaker: Skel.
sp.l: Faith little Tracy you are somewhat forward:
What, our Maid Marian leaping like a lad?
If you remember, Robin is your love:
Sir Thomas mantle yonder, not sir Iohn.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: But master, sir Iohn is my fellow, for I am
Much, the Millers son. Am I not?

sp.speaker: Sk.
sp.l: I know ye are sir:
And gentlemen, since you are thus prepared,
Go in, and bring your dumb scene on the stage,
And I, as Prologue, purpose to express
The ground whereon our history is laid.

body.stage: Trumpets sounde, enter first king Richard with drum and Auncient, giuing Ely a purse and scepter, his mother, and brother Iohn, Chester, Lester, Lacie, others at the kings appointment doing reuerence. The king goes in: presently Ely ascends the chaire, Chester, Iohn, and the Queene part displeasantly. Enter Robert, earle of Huntington, leading Marian, followes him Warman, and after Warman the Prior, Warman euer flattering and making curtsie, taking gifts of the Prior behinde, and his master before. Prince Iohn enters, offereth to take Marian. Queene Elinor enters, offering to pull Robin from her; but they infolde each other, and sit downe within the curteines, Warman with the Prior, sir Hugh Lacy, Lord Sentloe & sir Gilbert Broghton folde hands, and drawing the curteins, all (but the Prior) enter, and are kindely receiued by Robin Hoode. The curteins are againe shut.

sp.speaker: Sk.
sp.l: Sir Iohn, once more, bid your dumb shows come in;
That as they pass I may explain them all.
sp.stage: Enter king Richard with drumme and Ensigne, giuing Ely a purse, and scepter, his mother and brother Iohn, Chester, Lester, Lacie, others at the kings appointment, doing reuerence. The king goes in.
sp.l: Richard called Cor de Lion takes his leave,
Like the Lords Champion against the Pagan foes,
That spoil Iudea, and rich Palestine.
The rule of England and his princely seat,
He leaves with Ely, then Lord Chancellor:
To whom the mother Queen, her son, prince Iohn,
Chester, and all the Peers are sworn.
sp.stage: Ely ascends the chaire, Chester, Iohn and the Queene part displeasantly.
sp.l: Now reverend, Ely like the deputy
Of Gods great deputy ascends the throne:
Which the Queen mother, and ambitious Iohn
Repining at, raised many mutinies:
And how they ended you anon shall hear,
sp.stage: Enter Robert, earle of Huntington, leading Marian, followes him Warman, and after Warman the Prior, Warman euer flattering, and making curtsie, taking giftes of the Prior behinde, and his master before. Prince Iohn enters, offereth to take Marian, Queene Elinor enters, offering to pull Robin from her; but they infolde each other, and sit downe within the curteins,
sp.l: This youth that leads yon virgin by the hand
(As doth the Sun, the morning richly clad)
Is our Earl Robert, or your Robin Hood,
That in those days, was Earl of Huntington.
The ill faced miser, bribed in either hand,
Is Warman, once the Steward of his house,
Who Iudas like betrays his liberal Lord,
Into the hands of that relentless Prior,
Called Gilbert Hood, uncle to Huntington:
Those two that seek to part these lovely friends,
Are Elenor the Queen, and Iohn the Prince,
She loves earl Robert, he maid Marian,
But vainly: for their dear affect is such,
As only death can sunder their true loves.
Long had they loved, and now it is agreed,
This day they must be troth-plight, after wed.
At Huntingtons fair house a feast is held;
But envy turns it to a house of tears.
For those false guests, conspiring with the Prior,
To whom earl Robert greatly is in debt,
Mean at the banquet to betray the Earl,
Unto a heavy writ of outlawry.
The manner and escape you all shall see.

sp.speaker: Elt.
sp.l: Which all, good Skelton?

sp.speaker: Skel.
sp.l: Why all these lookers on:
Whom if we please, the king will sure be pleased.
Look to your entrance, get you in sir Iohn.
My shift is long, for I play Friar Tuck:
Wherein if Skelton have but any luck
He will thank his hearers oft, with many a duck.
For many talk of Robin Hood that never shot in his bow,
But Skelton writes of Robin Hood what he doth truly know.
Therefore I pray ye,
Contentedly stay ye,
And take no offending,
But sit to the ending.
Likewise I desire,
Yea would not admire
My rime so I shift.
For this is my drift,
So mought I well thrive,
To make ye all blithe:
But if ye once frown,
Poor Skelton goes down,
His labour and cost,
He thinketh all lost,
In tumbling of books
Of Marry go looks.
The Sheriff with staves,
With catchpoles and knaves,
Are coming, I see,
High time it is for me
To leave off my babble
And fond ribble rabble,
Therefore with this curtsey
A while I will leave ye.

body.stage: Enter, as it were in haste, the Prior of Yorke, the Sheriffe, Iustice Warman, Steward to Robin Hoode.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Here master Warman, there is a hundred crowns,
For your good will and furtherance in this.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: I thank you my Lord Prior, I must away
To shun suspicion, but be resolute,
And we will take him, have no doubt of it.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: But is Lord Sentloe and the other come?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Lord Sentloe, sir Hugh Lacie, and sir Gilbert Broghton
Are there, and as they promised you last night,
Will help to take him, when the Sheriff comes.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: A while farewell, and thanks to them and you.
Come master Sheriff, the outlawry is proclaimed,
Send therefore quickly for more company,
And at the back gate we will enter in.

sp.speaker: Sher.
sp.l: We shall have much ado I am afraid.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: No, they are very merry at a feast,
A feast, where Marian, daughter to Lord Lacy,
Is troth-plighted to wasteful Huntington.
And at the feast, are my especial friends,
Whom he suspects not: come we will have him, man,
And for your pains, here is a hundred marks.

sp.speaker: Sher.
sp.l: I thank your Lordship, we will be diligent.

body.stage: Enter Robin Hoode, little Iohn following him; the one earle of Huntington, the other his seruant, Robin hauing his napkin on his shoulder, as if hee were sodainly raised from dinner.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.l: As I am outlawed from my fame and state,
Be this day outlawed from the name of days:
Day luckless, outlaw lawless, both accursed,

body.stage: Flings away his napkin, hat, and sitteth downe.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Do not forget your honourable state,
Nor the true noblesse of your worthy house.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Do not persuade me: vain as vanity
Are all thy comforts, I am comfortless.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Hear me my Lord.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: What shall I hear thee say?
Already hast thou said too much to hear.
Already hast thou stabbed me with thy tongue,
And the wide wound with words will not be closed.
Am I not outlawed, by the Prior of Yorke,
Proclaimed in Court, in city, and in town,
A lawless person? this thy tongue reports:
And therefore seek not to make smooth my grief:
For the rough storm, thy windy words hath raised,
Will not be calmed, till I in grave be laid.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Have patience yet.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Yea, now indeed thou speakest.
Patience hath power to bear a greater cross
Then honours spoil, or any earthly loss.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Do so my Lord.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Aye, now I would begin:
But see, another Scene of grief comes in.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Why is my Lord so sad? wherefore so soon,
So suddenly arose ye from the board?
Alas my Robin, what distempering grief
Drinks up the roseate colour of thy cheeks?
Why art thou silent? answer me my love.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Let him, let him, let him make thee as sad.
He hath a tongue can banish thee from joy,
And chase thy crimson colour from thy cheeks.
Why speakest thou not? I pray thee little Iohn,
Let the short story of my long distress
Be uttered in a word. What meanest thou to protract?
Wilt thou not speak? then Marian list to me.
This day thou wert a maid, and now a spouse,
Anon (poor soul) a widow thou must be:
Thy Robin is an outlaw, Marian,
His goods and lands must be extended on,
Himself exiled from thee, thou kept from him,
By the long distance of unnumbered miles,
Faintest thou at this? speak to me Marian,
My old love newly met, part not so soon,
We have a little time to tarry yet.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: If but a little time, let me not stay,
Part we today, then will I die today.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: For shame my Lord, with courage of a man,
Bridle this over-grieving passion,
Or else dissemble it, to comfort her.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I like thy counsel. Marian, clear these clouds,
And with the sunny beams of thy bright eyes,
Drink up these mists of sorrow that arise.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: How can I joy, when thou art banished?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I tell thee love, my grief is counterfeit;
And I abruptly from the table rose,
The banquet being almost at an end,
Only to drive confused and sad thoughts
Into the minds of the invited guests.
For, gentle love, at great or nuptial feasts,
With Comic sports, or Tragic stately plays,
We use to recreate the feasted guests,
Which I am sure our kinsfolk do expect.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Of this what then? this seems of no effect.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Why thus of this, as little Iohn can tell,
I had bespoken quaint Comedians:
But great Iohn, Iohn the Prince, my Lieges brother,
My rival, Marian, he that crossed our love,
Hath crossed me in this jest, and at the Court,
Employs the Players, should have made us sport;
This was the tidings brought by little Iohn,
That first disturbed me, and begot this thought
Of sudden rising, which by this I know
Hath with amazement, troubled all our guests:
Go in, good love, thou as the Chorus shalt,
Express the meaning of my silent grief,
Which is no more but this; I only mean
(The more to honour our right noble friends)
Myself in person, to present some Scenes
Of tragic matter, or perchance of mirth,
Even such as first shall jump with my conceit.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: May I be bold thou hast the worst expressed?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Fair mistress, all is true my Lord hath said.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: It is, it is.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Speak not so hollow then,
So sigh, and sadly speak true sorrowing men.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Believe me love, believe me (I beseech)
My first Scene tragic is, therefore tragic speech,
And accents, fitting woeful action, I strive to get:
I pray thee sweet go in, and with thy sight,
Appease the many doubts that may arise.
That done, be thou their usher, bring them to this place,
And thou shalt see me with a lofty verse,
Bewitch the hearers ears, and tempt their eyes
To gaze upon the action that I use.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: If it be but a play, I will play my part:
But sure some earnest grief affrights my heart.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Let me entreat ye Madam not to fear,
For by the honesty of little Iohn,
It is but a tragic Scene we have in hand,
Only to fit the humour of the Queen,
Who is the chiefest at your troth-plight feast.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Then will I fetch her Highness and the rest.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Aye, that same jealous Queen, whose doting age
Envies the choice of my fair Marian,
She hath a hand in this.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Well, what of that?
Now must your honour leave these mourning tunes,
And thus by my aread you shall provide;
Your Plate and Jewels I will straight pack up,
And toward Notingham convey them hence,
At Rowford, Sowthan, Wortley, Hothersfield:
Of all your cattle, money shall be made,
And I at Mansfield will attend your coming,
Where we will determine, which way is best to take.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Well be it so, in Gods name let it be:
And if I can, Marian shall come with me.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Else care will kill her, therefore if you please,
At the utmost corner of the garden wall,
Soon in the evening wait for Marian,
And as I go I will tell her of the place,
Your horses at the Bell shall ready be,
I mean Belsauage, whence as citizens
That meant to ride for pleasure some small way,
You shall set forth.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Be it as thou dost say.
Farewell a while.
In spite of grief, thy love compels me smile:
But now our audience comes, we must look sad.

body.stage: Enter Queene Elinor, Marian, Sentloe, Lacie, Broghton, VVarman, Robins stewarde. As they meete, Iohn whispers with Marian.

sp.speaker: Que.
sp.l: How now my Lord of Huntington?
The mistress of your love, fair Marian,
Tells us your sudden rising from the banquet,
Was but a humour, which you mean to purge,
In some high Tragic lines, or Comic jests.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Sit down fair Queen (the Prologues part is played,
Marian hath told ye, what I bad her tell)
Sit down Lord Sentloe, cousin Lacy sit,
Sir Gilbert Broghton, yea, and Warman sit;
Though you my steward be, yet for your gathering wit,
I give you place, sit down, sit down I say,
Gods pity sit; it must, it must be so:
For you will sit, when I shall stand I know.
And Marian (you) may sit among the rest,
I pray ye do, or else rise, stand apart,
These helps shall be beholders of my smart.
You that with ruthless eyes my sorrows see,
And came prepared to feast at my sad fall,
Whose envy, greediness, and jealousy
Afford me sorrow endless, comfort small,
Know what you knew before, what you ordained
To cross the spousal banquet of my love,
That I am outlawed by the Prior of Yorke,
My traitorous uncle, and your trothless friend.
Smile you Queen Elinor? laughest thou Lord Sentloe?
Lacy lookest thou so blithe at my lament?
Broghton a smooth brow graceth your stern face:
And you are merry Warman at my moan.
The Queen except, I do you all defy.
You are a sort of fawning Sycophants,
That while the sun shine of my greatness dured,
Revelled out all my day for your delights,
And now ye see the black night of my woe
Overshade the beauty of my smiling good,
You to my grief add grief, and are agreed
With that false Prior, to reprieve my joys
From execution of all happiness.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Your honour thinks not ill of me, I hope.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Iudas speaks first, with, master is it I?
No, my false Steward, your accounts are true,
You have dishonoured me, I worshipped you.
You from a paltry pen and inkhorn clarke,
Bearing a buckram satchel at your belt,
Unto a Justice place I did prefer,
Where you unjustly have my tenants racked,
Wasted my treasure, and increased your store.
Your sire contented with a cottage poor,
Your mastership hath halls and mansions built,
Yet are you innocent, as clear from guilt,
As is the ravenous mastiff that hath spilt
The blood of a whole flock, yet slily comes
And couches in his kennel, with smeared chaps.
Out of my house, for yet my house it is,
And follow him ye catchpole bribed grooms:
For neither are ye Lords, nor Gentlemen,
That will be hired to wrong a Nobleman:
For hired ye were, last night, I know it I,
To be my guests, my faithless guests this day,
That your kind host you trothless might betray:
But hence, and help the Sheriff at the door,
Your worst attempt: fell traitors, as you be,
Avoid, or I will execute ye all,
Ere any execution come at me,
They ran away, so ends the tragedy.
Marian, by little Iohn, my mind you know,
If you will, do: if not, why, be it so.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: No words to me earl Robert ere you go?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: O to your Highness? yes, adieu proud Queen,
Had not you been, thus poor I had not been.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Thou wrongest me Robert, earl of Huntington,
And were it not for pity of this maid,
I would revenge the words that thou hast said.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Add not, fair Queen, distress unto distress:
But if you can, for pity make his less.

sp.speaker: Que.
sp.l: I can and will forget deserving hate,
And give him comfort in this woeful state.
Marian, I know Earl Roberts whole desire
Is to have thee with him from hence away:
And though I loved him dearly to this day;
Yet since I see he dearlier loveth thee,
Thou shalt have all the furtherance I may.
Tell me fair girl, and see thou truly tell,
Whether this night, tomorrow, or next day,
There be no appointment for to meet thy love.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: There is, this night there is, I will not lie,
And be it disappointed, I shall die.

sp.speaker: Que.
sp.l: Alas poor soul, my son, Prince Iohn my son,
With several troupes hath circuited the Court,
This house, the city, that thou canst not scape.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I will away with death, though he be grim,
If they deny me to go hence with him.

sp.speaker: Qu,
sp.l: Marian, thou shalt go with him clad in my attire,
And for a shift, I will put thy garments on,
It is not me, my son Iohn doth desire;
But Marian it is thee, he doteth on.
When thou and I are come into the field,
Or any other place where Robin stays,
Me in thy clothes, the ambush will beset,
Thee in my robes they dare not once approach:
So while with me a-reasoning they stay,
At pleasure thou with him mayst ride away.

sp.speaker: Mar,
sp.l: I am beholding to your Majesty,
And of this plot will send my Robin word.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Nay, never trouble him, lest it breed suspect:
But get thee in, and shift of thy attire,
My robe is loose, and it will soon be off,
Go gentle Marian, I will follow thee,
And from betrayers hands will set thee free.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I thank your Highness, but I will not trust ye,
My Robert shall have knowledge of this shift:
For I conceive already your deep drift.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Now shall I have my will of Huntington,
Who taking me this night for Marian,
Will harry me away in stead of her:
For he dares not stand trifling to confer:
Faith pretty Marian I shall meet with you,
And with your lovely sweet heart Robert too:
For when we come unto a baiting place,
If with like love my love he do not grace,
Of treason capital I will accuse him,
For traitorous forcing me out of the Court,
And guerdon his disdain with guilty death,
That of a Princes love so lightly weighs.

body.stage: Enter little Iohn, fighting with the Sheriffe and his men, Warman perswading him.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Warman stand off, tit tattle, tell not me what ye can do:
The goods I say are mine, and I say true.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: I say the Sheriff must see them ere they go.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: You say so Warman, little Iohn says no.

sp.speaker: Shre.
sp.l: I say I must for I am the kings Shrieve.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Your must is false, your office I believe.

sp.speaker: Watch.
sp.l: Down with him, down with him.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Ye bark at me like curs, but I will down
With twenty (stand, and who go theres) of you,
If ye stand long tempting my patience.
Why master Shrive, think you me a fool?
What justice is there you should search my trunks,
Or stay my goods for that my master owes?

sp.speaker: Shr.
sp.l: Here is Justice Warman, steward to your Lord,
Suspects some coin, some Jewels, or some plate
That longs unto your Lord, are in your trunks,
And the extent is out for all his goods:
Therefore we ought to see none he conveyed.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: True little Iohn, I am the sorrier.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: A plague upon ye else, how sore ye weep?
Why, say thou upstart, that there were some help,
Some little little help in this distress,
To aid our Lord and master comfortless;
Is it thy part, thou screenfaced snotty nose,
To hinder him that gave thee all thou hast?

body.stage: Enter Iustice Warmans wife, odly attyred.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Who is that husband? you, you, means he you?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Aye, byrlady is it, I thank him.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: Aye knave you, gods pity husband, why does not your worship send the knave to Newgate?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Well master Sheriff, shall I pass or no?

sp.speaker: Sher.
sp.l: Not without search.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Then here the casket stands,
Any, that dares, unto it set their hands,
Let him begin.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: Do husband, you are a Majesty, I warrant there is old knacks, chains and other toys.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: But not for you, good Madam beetle brows.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Out upon him. By my truly master Justice, and ye do not clap him up, I will sue a bill of remorse, and never come between a pair of sheets with ye. Such a knave as this, down with him I pray.

body.stage: Set vpon him. He knockes some downe.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: A good Lord, come not near good husband, only charge him; charge him. A good God; help, help.

body.stage: Enter Prince Iohn, the Bishoppe of Ely, the Prior of Yorke, with others. All stay.

sp.speaker: P. Iohn.
sp.l: What tumult have we here? who doth resist
The kings writs with such obstinate contempt?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: This knave.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: This Rebel.

sp.speaker: P. Iohn.
sp.l: How now little Iohn,
Have you no more discretion than you show?

sp.speaker: Ely.
sp.l: Lay hold, and clap the traitor by the heels.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: I am no traitor, my good Lord of Ely.
First hear me, then commit me if you please.

sp.speaker: P. Ioh.
sp.l: Speak and be brief.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Hear is a little box,
Containing all my gettings twenty year;
Which is mine own, and no man's but mine own:
This they would rifle, this I do defend,
And about this we only do contend.

sp.speaker: P. Ioh.
sp.l: You do the fellow wrong: his goods are his:
You only must extend upon the Earls.

sp.speaker: Prior.
sp.l: That was my Lord; but now is Robert Hood,
A simple yeoman as his servants were.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Back with that leg my Lord Prior: There be some, that were his servants, think foul scorn to be called yeomen.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: I cry your worship mercy, mistress Warman.
The squire your husband was his servant once.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: A scurvy squire, with reverence of these Lords.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Does he not speak treason prey.

sp.speaker: Ely.
sp.l: Sirrah, yea are too saucy, get you hence.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: But hear me first, my Lords, with patience.
This scoffing careless fellow, little Iohn,
Hath laden hence a horse, twixt him and Much,
A silly rude knave, Much the millers son.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: I am here to answer for myself, and have taken you in two lies at once. First, Much is no knave, neither was it a horse little Iohn and I loaded, but a little curtail, of some five handfuls high, sib to the Apes only beast at Parish garden.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: But master Warman, you have loaded carts,
And turned my Lords goods to your proper use:
Who ever hath the right, you do the wrong,
And are

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: What is he knave?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Unworthy to be named a man,

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.l: And I will be sworn for his wife,

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Aye, so thou mayst Nich.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: That she sets new marks of all my old Ladies linen (God rest her soul) and my young Lord never had them since.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Out, out, I took him them but to whiting, as God mend me.

sp.speaker: Ely.
sp.l: Leave off this idle talk, get ye both hence.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: I thank your Honours: we are not in love with being here; we must seek service that are masterless.

sp.speaker: Ely.
sp.l: Lord Prior of Yorke, here is your commission.
You are best make speed, lest in his country houses,
By his appointment, all his herds be sold.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: I thank your Honour, taking humble leave.

sp.speaker: Ely.
sp.l: And master VVarman, here is your Patent sealed,
For the high Sheriffewick of Notingham:
Except the king our master do repeal
This gift of ours.

sp.speaker: Pr. Ioh.
sp.l: Let him the while possess it.

sp.speaker: Ely.
sp.l: In gods name let him, he hath my good will.

sp.speaker: P. Ioh.
sp.l: Well Warman, this proud Priest I can not brooke.
But to our other matter, send thy wife away.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: Go in good wife, the Prince with me hath private conference.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: By my troth ye will anger me: now ye have the Pattern, ye should call me nothing but mistress Sheriff: for I tell you I stand upon my replications.

sp.speaker: P. Ioh.
sp.l: Thinkest thou that Marian means
To scape this evening hence with Robin Hood?
The horse boy told me so, and here he comes,
Disguised like a citizen methinks.
Warman let us in, I will fit him presently,
Only for Marian am I now his enemy.

body.stage: Exeunt. Enter Robin like a citizen.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Earl Iohn and Warman, two good friends of mine:
I think they knew me not, or if they did
I care not what can follow, I am sure
The sharpest end is death, and that will come.
But what of death or sorrow do I dream?
My Marian, my fair life, my beauteous love,
Is coming, to give comfort to my grief,
And the sly Queen, intending to deceive,
Hath taught us how we should her sleights deceive.
But who is this? gods pity, here is Prince Iohn,
We shall have some good rule with him anon.

sp.speaker: P. Ioh.
sp.l: God even sir: this clear evening should portend
Some frost I think: how judge you honest friend?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I am not weather wise: but it may be,
We shall have hard frost: for true charity,
Good dealing, faithful friendship, honesty,
Are chill-cold, dead with cold.

sp.speaker: P. Ioh.
sp.l: O good sir, stay.
That frost hath lasted many a bitter day.
Know ye no frozen hearts that are beloved?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Love is a flame, a fire, that being moved,
Still brighter grows: but say, are you beloved?

sp.speaker: P. Ioh.
sp.l: I would be, if I be not: but pass that.
Are ye a dweller in this city, pray?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I am: and for a Gentlewoman stay,
That rides some four or five mile in great haste.

sp.speaker: P. Ioh.
sp.l: I see your labour, sir, is not in waste.
For here comer two: are either of these yours?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Both are, one must.

sp.speaker: P. Iohn.
sp.l: Which do you most respect?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: The youngest, and the fairest I reject.

sp.speaker: P. Io.
sp.l: Robin, I will try you whether ye say true.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: As you with me, so Iohn I will jest with you.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Marian, let me go first to Robin Hood,
And I will tell him what we do intend.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Do what your Highness please, your will is mine.

sp.speaker: P. Ioh.
sp.l: My mother is with gentle Marian:
O it doth grieve her to be left behind.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Shall we away my Robin, lest the Queen
Betray our purpose, sweet let us away:
I have great will to go, no heart to stay.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Away with thee? No: get thee far away
From me foul Marian, fair though thou be named:
For thy bewitching eyes have raised storms,
That have my name and noblesse ever shamed:
Prince Iohn, my dear friend once, is now, for thee,
Become an unrelenting enemy,

sp.speaker: P. Ioh.
sp.l: But I will relent, and love thee, if thou leave her.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: And Elinor my Sovereigns mother Queen,
That yet retains true passion in her breast,
Stands mourning yonder. Hence, I thee detest:
I will submit me to her Majesty.
Great Princess, if you will but ride with me,
A little of my way, I will express
My folly past, and humble pardon beg.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I grant, earl Robert, and I thank thee too.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: She is not the Queen, sweet Robin it is I.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Hence Sorceress, thy beauty I defy.
If thou have any love at all to me,
Bestow it on Prince Iohn: he loveth thee.

sp.speaker: P. Ioh.
sp.l: And I will love thee Robin, for this deed,
And help thee too, in thy distressful need.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Wilt thou not stay nor speak, proud Huntington?
Aye me, some whirlwind hurries them away.

sp.speaker: P. Ioh.
sp.l: Follow him not fair love, that from thee flies:
But fly to him that gladly follows thee.
Wilt thou not girl? turnest thou away from me?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Nay, we shall have it then,
If my quaint son, his mother gin to court.

sp.speaker: P. Io.
sp.l: Wilt thou not speak, fair Marian, to prince Iohn,
That loves thee well?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Good sir I know you do.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: That can maintain thee?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Aye, I know you can:
But hitherto I have maintained you.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: My princely mother?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Aye, my princely son.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Is Marian then gone hence with Huntington?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Aye, she is gone, ill may they either thrive.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Mother, they must go whom the devil drives.
For your sharpe fury, and infernal rage,
Your scorn of me, your spite to Marian,
Your over-doting love to Huntington,
Hath crossed yourself, and me it hath undone.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Aye, in mine own deceit, have met deceit:
In brief, the manner thus I will repeat;
I knew, with malice that the Prior of Yorke
Pursued Earl Robert; and I furthered it;
Though God can tell for love of Huntington.
For thus I thought, when he was in extremes,
Need, and my love would win some good regard
From him to me, If I relieved his want.
To this end came I to the mock-spouse feast:
To this end made I change for Marians weed,
That me, for her, Earl Robert should receive:
But now I see they both of them agreed,
In my deceit, I might myself deceive.
Come in with me, come in and meditate
How to turn love, to never changing hate.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: In by yourself: I pass not for your spells.
Of youth and beauty still you are the foe:
The curse of Rosamond rests on your head,
Fair Rose confounded by your cankers hate.
O that she were not as to me she is,
A mother, whom by nature I must love,
Then would I tell her she were too too base,
To dote thus on a banished careless groom;
Then should I tell her that she were too fond,
To thrust fair Marian to an exiles hand.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: My Lord, my Lord of Ely sends for you,
About important business of the state.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Tell the proud Prelate I am not disposed,
Nor in estate to come at his command.
Be gon with that, or tarry and take this.
'swounds are ye listening for an after-arrant?
I will follow, with revengeful murderous hate,
The banished, beggared, bankrupt Huntington.

sp.speaker: Ley.
sp.l: How now Prince Iohn? body of me, I muse
What mad moods toss ye, in this busy time,
To wound the messenger that Ely sent,
By our consents? i'faith ye did not well.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Leyster, I meant it Ely, not his man:
His servants head but bleeds: he headless shall
From all the issues of his traitor neck,
Pour streams of blood, till he be bloodless left:
By earth it shall, by heaven it shall be so,
Leister, it shall though all the world say no.

sp.speaker: Lei.
sp.l: It shall, it shall, but how shall it be done?
Not with a stormy tempest of sharpe words,
But slow, still speeches, and effecting deeds.
Here comes old Lacy and his brother Hugh.
One is our friend, the other is not true.

body.stage: Enter Lord Lacy, sir Hugh, and his boy.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: Hence treacher as thou art: by Gods blessed mother
I will lop thy legs off, though thou be my brother,
If with thy flattering tongue thou seek to hide
Thy traitorous purpose. Ah poor Huntington,
How in one hour have villains thee undone?

sp.speaker: Hugh.
sp.l: If you will not believe what I have sworn,
Conceit your worst. My Lord of Ely knows
That what I say, is true.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Still facest thou?
Draw boy, and quickly see that thou defend thee.

sp.speaker: Lei.
sp.l: Patience Lord Lacy, get you gon sir Hugh,
Provoke him not, for he hath told you true:
You know it, that I know the Prior of Yorke,
Together with my good Lord Chancellor,
Corrupted you, Lord Sentloe, Broghton, Warman,
To feast with Robert on his day of fall.

sp.speaker: Hugh.
sp.l: They lie that say it; I defy ye all.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Now by the Rood thou liest. Warman himself,
That creeping Iudas, joyed, and told it me.

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: Let me, my Lords, revenge me of this wretch,
By whom my daughter and her love were lost.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: For her, let me revenge; with bitter cost,
Shall sir Hugh Lacy and his fellows buy
Fair Marians loss, lost by their treachery.
And thus I pay it.

body.stage: Stabs him, he falles, boy runnes in.

sp.speaker: Leist.
sp.l: Sure payment Iohn.

sp.speaker: Lacy:
sp.l: There let the villain lie:
For this, old Lacie honours thee, prince Iohn.
One treacherous soul, is sent to answer wrong.

body.stage: Enter Ely, Chester, officers, Hugh Lacies boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Here, here, my Lord,
Look where my master lies.

sp.speaker: Ely.
sp.l: What murderous had hath killed this gentle knight,
Good sir Hugh Lacy, steward of my lands?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Ely, he died by this princely hand.

sp.speaker: Ely.
sp.l: Unprincely deed. Death asketh death you know.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Arrest him officers.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: O sir, I will obey; you will take bail, I hope.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: It is more, sir, than he may.

sp.speaker: Ely.
sp.l: Chester, he may by law, and therefore shall.

sp.speaker: Lei.
sp.l: Who are his bail?

sp.speaker: Lacy.
sp.l: I.
And I.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Yon are confederates.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: Holy Lord, you lie.
Be reverent, Prince Iohn: my Lord of Ely,
You know, is Regent for his Majesty.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: But here are Letters from his Majesty,
Sent out of Ioppa, in the holy land,
To you, to these, to me, to all the State;
Containing a repeal of that large grant,
And free authority to take the seal,
Into the hands of three Lords temporal,
And the Lord Archbishop of Roan, he sent.
And he shall yield it: or as Lacy lies,
Desertfully, for pride and treason stabbed,
He shall ere long lie. Those that intend as I
Follow this steely ensign, lift on high.

body.stage:
Lifts vp his drawne sword:
Exit, cum Lester and Lacy.

sp.speaker: Ely.
sp.l: A thousand thousand ensigns of sharpe steel,
And feathered arrows, from the bow of death,
Against proud Iohn, wronged Ely will employ.
My Lord of Chester, let me have your aid,
To lay the pride of haught usurping Iohn.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: Some other course than war let us bethink:
If it may be, let not uncivil broils,
Our civil hands defile.

sp.speaker: Ely.
sp.l: God knows that I,
For quiet of the Realm, would aught forbear:
But give me leave, my noble Lord to fear,
When one, I dearly loved, is murdered,
Under the colour of a little wrong,
Done to the wasteful earl of Huntington:
Whom Iohn, I know, doth hate unto the death,
Only for love he bears to Lacies daughter.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: My Lord, its plain this quarrel is but picked
For an inducement to a greater ill:
But we will call the Council of Estate,
At which the mother Queen shall present be:
Thither by summons shall Prince Iohn be called,
Lester and Lacy, who, it seems,
Favour some factious purpose of the Prince.

sp.speaker: Ely.
sp.l: You have advised well, my Lord of Chester,
And as you counsel, so do I conclude.

body.stage: Enter Robin Hoode>, Matilda, at one doore, little Iohn, and Much the millers sonne at another doore.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.l: Luck I beseech thee, Marry and amen,
Blessing betide hem, it be them indeed,
Ah my good Lord, for and my little Lady.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: What? Much and Iohn, well met in this ill time.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: In this good time my Lord; for being met,
The world shall not depart us till we die.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Sayst thou me so Iohn? as I am true maid,
If I live long, well shall thy love be paid.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Well, there be on us, simple though we stand here, have as much love in hem as little Iohn.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Much, I confess thou lovest me very much,
And I will more reward it than with words.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Nay I know that, but we millers children love the cog a little, and the fair speaking.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: And is it possible that Warmans spite
Should stretch so far, chat he doth hunt the lives,
Of bonnie Scarlet, and brother Scathlock.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: O, Aye sir. Warman came but yesterday to take charge of the Jail at Notingham, and this day he says he will hang the two outlaws: he means to set them at liberty.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Such liberty God send the peevish wretch
In his most need.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Now by my honours hope,
Yet buried in the low dust of disgrace,
He is to blame: say Iohn, where must they die?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Yonder is their mothers house, and here the tree,
Whereon (poor men) they must forgo their lives:
And yonder comes a lazy, losel Friar,
That is appointed for their confessor,
Who when we brought your money to their mothers:
Was wishing her to patience for their deaths.

body.stage: Enter Frier Tucke, and Ralphe, Warmans man.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: I am timorous sir, that the prisoners are passed from the Jail.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Soft sirrah, by my order I protest,
Ye are too forward: it is no game, no jest
We go about.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Matilda, walk afore,
To widow Scarlets house: look where it stands:
Much, man your Lady: little Iohn and I
Will come unto you thither presently.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Come Madam, my Lord has pointed the properer man to go before ye.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Be careful Robin in this time of fear,

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Now by the relics of the holy Mass,
A pretty girl, a very bonny lass.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Friar, how like you her?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Marry, by my hood,
I like her well, and wish her naught but good.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.p: Ye protract master Friar. I obsecrate ye with all courtesy, omitting complement, you would vouch, or deign to proceed.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Deign, vouch, protract, complement, obsecrate?
Why good man tricks, who taught you thus to prate?
Your name, your name, were you never christened?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: My nomination Radulfe is or Ralph,
Vulgars corruptly use to call me Rafe.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: O foul corruption of base palliardize,
When idiots witless travel to be wise.
Age barbarous, times impious, men vicious,
Able to upraise,
Men dead many days,
That wonted to praise,
The Rimes and the lays
Of Poets Laureate,
Whose verse did decorate,
And their lines illustrate
Both Prince and Potentate.
These from their graves,
See asses and knaves,
Base idiot slaves,
With boastings and braves,
Offer to vpstie,
To the heavens hie,
With vain foolery,
And rude ribaldry.
Some of them write
Of beastly delight,
Suffering their lines,
To flatter these times,
With Panderism base,
And lust do uncase,
From the placket to the pap:
God send them ill hap.
Some like quaint pedants,
Good wits true recreants,
Ye cannot beseech
From pure Priscian speech.
Divers as nice,
Like this odd vice,
Are wordmakers daily.
Others in curtsey
When ever they meet ye,
With new fashions greet ye,
Changing each conge,
Sometime beneath knee,
With, good sir, pardon me,
And much more foolery,
Paltry, and foppery,
Dissembling knavery:
Hands sometime kissing,
But honesty missing.
God give no blessing,
To such base counterfeiting.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Stop master Skelton: whither will you run?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Gods pity sir Iohn Eltam, little Iohn,
I had forgot myself; but to our play.
Come, good man fashions, let us go our way,
Unto this hanging business: would, for me,
Some rescue, or reprieve might set them free.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.l: Heardest thou not, little Iohn the Friars speech,
Wishing for rescue, or a quick reprieve?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: He seems like a good fellow, my good Lord.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: He is a good fellow Iohn, upon my word.
Lend me thy horn, and get thee in to Much,
And when I blow this horn, come both and help me.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Take heed my Lord: the villain Warman knows you,
And ten to one, he hath a writ against you.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Fear not: below the bridge a poor blind man doth dwell,
With him I will change my habit, and disguise,
Only be ready when I call for ye:
For I will save their lives, if it may be.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: I will do what you would immediately.

body.stage: Enter Warman, Scarlet, and Scathlock bounde, Frier Tuck as their confessor, Officers with halberts.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Master Friar, be brief, delay no time:
Scarlet and Scathlock, never hope for life,
Here is the place of execution,
And you must answer law, for what is done.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Well, if there be no remedy, we must:
Though it ill seemeth Warman, thou shouldst be
So bloody to pursue our lives thus cruelly.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.l: Our mother saved thee from the gallows, Warman,
His father did prefer thee to thy Lord:
One mother had we both, and both our fathers,
To thee and to thy father, were kind friends.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Good fellows, here you see his kindness ends.
What he was once, he doth not now consider:
You must consider of your many sins:
This day, in death, your happiness begins.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: If you account it happiness, good Friar,
To bear us company, I you desire:
The more the merrier, we are honest men.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Ye were first outlaws, then ye proved thieves,
And now all carelessly ye scoff at death:
Both of your fathers were good honest men;
Your mother lives, their widow, in good fame:
But you are scapethrifts, unthrifts, villains knaves,
And as ye lived by shifts, shall die with shame.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.l: Warman, good words, for all your bitter deeds:
Ill speech, to wretched men, is more than needs.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Sir, retire ye, for it hath thus succeeded, the carnifex, or executor, riding on an ill curtal, hath titubated or stumbled, and is now cripplefied, with broken or fractured tibias, and sending you tidings of success, saith, yourself must be his deputy.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Ill luck: but sirrah, you shall serve the turn:
The cords that bind them, you shall hang them in.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: How are you, sir, of me opinionated? Not to possess your seneschalship, or sheriualtie, not to be earl of Notingham, will Ralph be nominated by the base scandalous vociferation of a hangman.

body.stage: Enter Robin Hoode, like an old man.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Where is the shrieve, kind friends? I you beseech,
With his good worship, let me have some speech.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Here is the Sheriff, father, this is he.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Friar, good alms, and many blessings thank thee.
Sir, you are welcome to this troublous shire:
Of this days execution did I hear.
Scarlet and Scathlocke murdered my young son,
Me have they robbed, and helplessly undone.
Revenge I would, but I am old and dry:
Wherefore, sweet master, for saint charity,
Since they are bound, deliver them to me,
That for my sons blood, I revenged may be.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: This old man lies, we never did him such wrong.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I do not lie, you wot it too too well,
The deed was such, as you may shame to tell.
But I with all entreats might not prevail
With your stern stubborn minds, bent all to blood.
Shall I have such revenge then master Sheriff,
That with my sons loss, may suffice myself?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Do father what thou wilt, for they must die.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: I never heard them touched with blood till now.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Notorious villains, and they made their brags,
The earl of Huntington would save their lives:
But he is down the wind, as all such shall,
That revel, waste and spend, and take no care.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: My horn once winded, I will unbind my belt,
Whereat the swords and bucklers are fast tied.

sp.speaker: Scath.
sp.l: Thanks to your Honour. Father we confess,
And were our arms unbound, we would upheave
Our sinful hands with sorrowing hearts to heaven.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: I will unbind you, with the Sheriffs leave.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Do: help him Ralphe; go to them master Friar.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.l: And as ye blew your horns, at my sons death,
So will I sound your knell, with my best breath:
And here is a blade, that hangeth at my belt,
Shall make ye feele in death, what my son felt.

body.stage: Enter little Iohn, Much, Scarlet and Scathlock: Fight: the Frier, making as if he helpt the Sheriffe, knockes downe his men, crying, keepe the kings peace.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.l: O they must be hanged father:

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Thy master and thyself supply their rooms.
Warman, approach me not, tempt not my wrath.
For if thou do, thou diest remediless.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: It is the outlawed earl of Huntington,
Down with him Friar: O thou dost mistake.
Fly Ralph, we die else, let us raise the shire.

body.stage: Sheriffe runnes away, and his men.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Farewell earl Robert, as I am true Friar,
I had rather be thy clarke, than serve the Prior.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: A jolly fellow, Scarlet knowest thou him?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: He is of Yorke, and of Saint Maries Cloister:
There where your greedy uncle is Lord Prior.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: O murrain on ye, have you two scaped hanging? Hark ye my Lord, these two fellows kept at Barnsdale seven year, to my knowledge, and no man

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Here is no biding masters, get ye in,
Take a short blessing at your mothers hands.
Much, bear them company, make Matilda merry:
Iohn and myself will follow presently.
Iohn, on a sudden thus I am resolved,
To keep in Sherewodde, till the kings return,
And being outlawed, lead an outlaws life.
(Seven years these brethren, being yeoman's sons,
Lived and scaped the malice of their foes)
How thinkest thou little Iohn of my intent?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: I like your Honours purpose exceeding well.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Nay, no more honour, I pray thee little Iohn:
Henceforth I will be called Robin Hood,
Matilda shall be my maid Marian.
Come Iohn, friends all, for now begins the game:
And after our deserts, so grow our fame.

body.stage: Exeunt. Enter Prince Iohn and his Lords, with souldiers.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Now is this Comet shot into the sea,
Or lies like slime, upon the sullen earth:
Come, he is dead, else should we hear of him.

sp.speaker: Sals.
sp.l: I know not what to think herein, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Ely is not the man I took him for,
I am afraid we shall have worse than he.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Why good Fitzwater, whence doth spring your fear?

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Him for his pride, we justly have suppressed:
But prouder climbers are about to rise.

sp.speaker: Sals.
sp.l: Name them Fitzwater, know you any such?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Fitzwater means not anything, I know:
For if he did, his tongue would tell his heart.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: An argument of my free heart my Lord,
That lets the world be witness of my thought.
When I was taught, true dealing kept the school:
Deeds were sworn partners with protesting words;
We said and did, these say and never mean.
This upstart protestation of no proof:
This, I beseech you sir accept my love;
Command me, use me, O you are to blame,
That do neglect my everlasting zeal,
My dear, my kind affect: when God can tell,
A sudden puff of wind, a lightning flash,
A bubble on the stream doth longer endure,
Than doth the purpose of their promise bide.
A shame upon this peevish Apish age,
These crouching hypocrite dissembling times.
Well, well, God rid the Patrons of these crimes,
Out of this land. I have an inward fear,
This ill, well seeming, sin, will be bought dear.

sp.speaker: Sals.
sp.l: My Lord Fitzwater is inspired I think.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Aye, with some devil: let the old fool dote.

body.stage: Enter Queene mother, Chester, Sheriffe, Kent souldiers.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: From the pursuing of the hateful Priest,
And bootless search of Ely are we come.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: And welcome is your sacred Majesty.
And Chester welcome too, against your will.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: Unwilling men come not without constraint:
But uncompelled comes Chester to this place,
Telling thee Iohn, that thou art much to blame,
To chase hence Ely, Chancellor to the king,
To set thy footsteps on the cloth of state,
And seat thy body in thy brothers throne.

sp.speaker: Sals.
sp.l: Who should succeed the brother, but the brother?

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: If one were dead, one should succeed the other.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: My son is king, my son then ought to reign.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: One son is king, the State allows not twain.

sp.speaker: Sals.
sp.l: The subjects many years the king have missed.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.l: But subjects must not choose what king they list.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Richard hath conquered kingdoms in the East.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: A sign he will not lose this in the West.

sp.speaker: Sals.
sp.l: By Salsburies Honour I will follow Iohn.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: So Chester will, to shun commotion.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Why? Iohn shall be but Richards deputy.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: To that, Fitzwater gladly doth agree.
And look to it Lady, mind king Richards love:
As you will answer it, do the king no wrong.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Well said old conscience, you keep still one song.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: In your contentious humours noble Lords,
Peers, and upholders of the English State,
Iohn silent stood, as one that did await
What sentence ye determined for my life:
But since you are agreed that I shall bear
The weighty burthen of this kingdoms state,
Till the return of Richard, our dread king:
I do accept the charge, and thank you all,
That think me worthy of so great a place.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We all confirm you Richards deputy.

sp.speaker: Sals.
sp.l: Now shall I plague proud Chester.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Sit you sure Fitzwater.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: For peace, I yield to wrong.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Now old man, for your daughter.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: To see wrong rule, my eyes run streams of water.

body.stage: A noyse within. Enter a Collier, crying a monster.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: A monster, a monster: bring her out Robin, a monster, a monster.

sp.speaker: Sals.
sp.l: Peace gaping fellow: knowest thou where thou art?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Why? I am in Kent, within a mile of Douer.
'sblood, where I am, peace, and a gaping fellow?
For all your dagger, wert not for your ging,
I would knock my whipstock on your addle head.
Come out with the monster, Robin.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.p: I come, I come, help me she scratches.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I will gee her the lash: come out ye bearded witch.

body.stage: Bring forth Ely, with a yarde in his hand, and linnen cloath>, drest like a woman.

sp.speaker: Ely.
sp.l: Good fellows let me go, there is gold to drink.
I am a man, though in a woman's weeds.
Yonder is Prince Iohn, I pray ye let me go.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: What rude companions have we yonder Salsbury?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Shall we take his money?

sp.speaker: 2. Col.
sp.p: No, no; this is the thief that robbed master Mighels, and came in like a woman in labour, I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Sals.
sp.l: Who have ye here, honest colliers?

sp.speaker: 2. Col.
sp.p: A monster, a monster: a woman with a beard, a man in a petticoat. A monster, a monster.

sp.speaker: Sals.
sp.l: What my good Lord of Ely, is it you?
Ely is taken, here is the Chancellor.

sp.speaker: 1. Col.
sp.p: Pray God we be not hanged for this trick?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: What my good Lord?

sp.speaker: Ely.
sp.l: Aye, Aye, ambitious Lady.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Who, my Lord Chancellor?

sp.speaker: Ely.
sp.l: I, you proud usurper.

sp.speaker: Sals.
sp.l: What, is your surplice turned to a smock?

sp.speaker: Ely.
sp.l: Peace Salsbury, thou changing weathercock.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: Alas my Lord, I grieve to see this sight.

sp.speaker: Ely.
sp.l: Chester, it will be day for this dark night.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Ely, thou wert the foe to Huntington:
Robin thou knewest, was my adopted son:
O Ely, thou to him wert too too cruel,
With him fled hence Matilda, my fair Jewel:
For their wrong Ely, and thy haughty pride,
I helped earl Iohn: but now I see thee low,
At thy distress, my heart is full of woe.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Needs must I see Fitzwaters overthrow:
Iohn, I affect him not, he loves not thee,
Remove him Iohn, lest thou removed be.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Mother, let me alone: by one and one,
I will not leave one, that envies our good.
My Lord of Salsbury, give these honest colliers,
For taking Ely, each a hundred marks.

sp.speaker: Sals.
sp.l: Come fellows, go with me.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Thank ye faith: farewell monster.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Sheriff of Kent, take Ely to your charge,
From Shrieve to Shrieve, send him to Notingham:
Where Warman, by our Patent, is high Shrieve.
There as a traitor let him be close kept,
And to his trial we will follow straight.

sp.speaker: Ely.
sp.l: A traitor, Iohn?

sp.speaker: Pr. Ioh.
sp.l: Do not expostulate.
You at your trial shall have time to prate.

sp.speaker: Firz.
sp.l: God for thy pity, what a time is here?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Right gracious mother, would yourself and Chester
Would but withdraw you for a little space,
While I confer with my good Lord Fitzwater.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: My Lord of Chester, will you walk aside?

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.l: Whether your Highness please, thither I will.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Soldiers, attend the person of our mother.
Noble Fitzwater, now we are alone,
What oft I have desired, I will entreat,
Touching Matilda, fled with Huntington.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Of her what would you touch? Touching her flight,
She is fled hence with Robert, her true knight.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Robert is outlawed, and Matilda free.
Why through his fault, should she exiled be?
She is your comfort, all your ages bliss.
Why should your age, so great a comfort miss?
She is all Englands beauty, all her pride.
In foreign lands, why should that beauty bide?
Call her again Fitzwater, call again
Guiltless Matilda, beauties sovereign.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: I grant prince Iohn, Matilda was my joy,
And the fair sun, that kept old winters frost,
From griping dead the marrow of my bones:
And she is gone, yet where she is, God wot,
Aged Fitzwater truly guesseth not:
But where she is, there is kind Huntington:
With my fair daughter, is my noble son.
If he may never be recalled again,
To call Matilda back it is in vain.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Living with him, she lives in vicious state,
For Huntington is excommunicate:
And till his debts be paid, by Romes decree,
It is agreed, absolved he cannot be:
And that can never be. So never wife,
But in a loathed adulterous beggars life,
Must fair Matilda live: this you may amend,
And win Prince Iohn your ever during friend.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: As how, as how?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Call her from him: bring her to Englands Court,
Where like fair Phoebe, she may sit as Queen,
Over the sacred Honourable maids,
That do attend the royal Queen, my mother.
There shall she live a Princes Cynthia,
And Iohn will be her true Endimion.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: By this construction, she should be the Moon,
And you would be the man within the Moon.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: A pleasant exposition, good Fitzwater:
But if it fell so out, that I fell in,
You of my full joys should be chief partaker.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Iohn I defy thee: by my Honours hope,
I will not bear this base indignity:
Take to thy tools. Thinkst thou a Noble man
Will be a Pander to his proper child?
For what intendest thou else? seeing I know,
Earl Clepstowes daughter is thy married wife.
Come, if thou be a right Plantaginet,
Draw and defend thee: o our Lady help
True English Lords, from such a tyrant Lord.
What, doest thou think I jest? Nay by the Rood,
I will lose my life, or purge thy lustful blood.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: What my old Ruffian, lie at your ward?
Have at your froward bosom, old Fitzwater.

body.stage: Fight: Iohn falles. Enter Queene, Chester, Salsbury hastily.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: O that thou wert not Royal Richards brother,
Thou shouldst here die in presence of thy mother.
sp.stage: Iohn rises, all compasse Fitzwater, Fitzwater chafes.
sp.l: What is he up? Nay Lords, then give us leave.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: What means this rage Fitzwater?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Lay hands upon the Bedlam, traitorous wretch.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Nay hale him hence: and hear you old Fitzwater?
See that you stay not five days in the Realm:
For if you do, you die remediless.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Speak Lords, do you confirm what he hath said?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: He is our Prince, and he must be obeyed.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Hearken earl Iohn, but one word will I say.

sp.speaker: Prin. Ioh.
sp.l: I will not hear thee, neither will I stay.
Thou knowest thy time.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Will not your Highness hear?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: No: thy Matilda robbed me of my dear.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: I aided thee in battle Salsbury.

sp.speaker: Sals.
sp.l: Prince Iohn is moved, I dare not stay with thee.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Against thee and Ely, Chester, was I foe?
And dost thou stay to aggravate my woe?

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: No, good Fitzwater, Chester doth lament
Thy wrong, thy sudden banishment.
Whence grew the quarrel betwixt the Prince and thee?

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Chester, the devil tempted old Firzwater,
To be a Pander to his only daughter,
And my great heart (impatient) forced my hand,
In my true Honours right to challenge him:
Alas the while, wrong will not be reproved.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: Farewell Fitzwater: wheresoever thou be,
By letters, I beseech thee, send to me.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Chester, I will, I will.
Heavens turn, to good, this woe, this wrong, this ill.

body.stage: Enter Scathlocke and Scarlet, winding their hornes at seuerall doores. To them enter Robin Hoode, Matilda all in greene, Scathlockes mother, Much, little Iohn, all the men with bowes and arrowes.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Widow, I wish thee homeward now to wend:
Least Warmans malice work thee any wrong.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Master I will, and mickle good attend
On thee, thy love, and all these yeomen strong.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Forget not widow, what you promise me.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.l: O Aye mistress, for gods sake lets have Iinny.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: You shall have Iinny sent you with all speed.
Sons farewell, and by your mothers reed,
Love well your master: blessing ever fall
On him, your mistress, and these yeomen tall.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: God be with you mother, have much mind I pray on Much, your son, and your daughter Iinny.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Wind once more, jolly huntsmen, all your horns:
Whose shrill sound, with the echoing woods assist,
Shall ring a sad knell for the fearful Deer,
Before our feathered shafts, deaths winged darts,
Bring sudden summons for their fatal ends.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: It is full seven years since we were outlawed first,
And wealthy Sherewood was our heritage:
For all those years we reigned uncontrolled:
From Barnsdale shrogs, to Notinghams red cliffs,
At Blithe and Tickhill were we welcome guests.
Good George a Green at Bradford was our friend,
And wanton Wakefields Pinner loved us well.
At Barnsley dwells a Potter tough and strong,
That never brooked, we brethren should have wrong.
The Nuns of Farnsfield, pretty Nuns they be,
Gave napkins, shirts, and bands to him and me.
Bateman of Kendall, gave us Kendall green,
And Sharpe of Leedes, sharpe arrows for us made:
At Rotheram dwelt our bower, God him bliss,
Iackson he hight, his bows did never miss.
This for our good, our scathe let Scathlocke tell,
In merry Mansfield, how it once befell.

sp.speaker: Scath.
sp.l: In merry Mansfield, on a wrestling day,
Prizes there were, and yeomen came to play:
My brother Scarlet and myself were twain:
Many resisted, but it was in vain,
For of them all we won the mastery,
And the gilt wreathes, were given to him and me.
There by sir Doncaster of Hethersfield,
We were bewrayed, beset, and forced to yield:
And so borne bound, from thence to Notingham,
Where we lay doomed to death, till Warman came.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Of that enough. What cheer my dearest love?

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: O good cheer anon sir, she shall have venison her bellyful.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Matilda is as joyful of thy good,
As joy can make her: how fares Robin Hood?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Well my Matilda, and if thou agree,
Nothing but mirth shall wait on thee and me.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: O God, how full of perfect mirth were I,
To see thy grief turned to true jollity!

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Give me thy hand; now gods curse on me light,
If I forsake not grief, in griefs despite.
Much, make a cry, and yeomen stand ye round:
I charge ye never more let woeful sound
Be heard among ye; but what ever fall,
Laugh grief to scorn; and so make sorrows small.
Much, make a cry, and loudly little Iohn.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: O God, O God, help, help, help, I am undone, I am undone.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Why how now Much? peace, peace, you roaring slave.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: My master bid me cry, and I will cry till he bid me leave; Help, help, help: Aye marry will I.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Peace Much; read on the Articles good Iohn.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: First, no man must presume to call our master,
By name of Earl, Lord, Baron, Knight, or Squire:
But simply by the name of Robin Hood.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Say yeomen, to this order will ye yield?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We yield to serve our master Robin Hood.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Next it is agreed (if thereto she agree)
That fair Matilda henceforth change her name,
And while it is the chance of Robin Hood,
To live in Sherewodde a poor outlaws life,
She, by maid Marians name, be only called.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I am contented; read on little Iohn,
Henceforth let me be named maid Marian.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Thirdly no yeoman, following Robin Hood
In Sherewod, shall use widow, wife, or maid,
But by true labour, lustful thoughts expel.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: How like ye this?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Master, we like it well.

sp.speaker: Muc.
sp.p: But I cry no to it. What shall I do with Iinny then?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Peace Much; go forward with the orders, fellow Iohn.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Fourthly, no passenger with whom ye meet,
Shall ye let pass till he with Robin feast:
Except a Post, a Carrier, or such folk,
As use with food to serve the market towns.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: An order which we gladly will observe.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Fifthly, yon never shall the poor man wrong,
Nor spare a Priest, a usurer, or a clarke.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Nor a fair wench, meet we her in the dark.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Lastly, you shall defend with all your power,
Maids, widows, Orphans, and distressed men.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: All these we vow to keep, as we are men.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Then wend ye to the Greenewod merrily,
And let the light Roes bootless from ye run.
Marian and I, as Sovereigns of your toils,
Will wait, within our bower, your bent bows spoils.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.l: I will among them master.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Marian, thou seest though courtly pleasures want,
Yet country sport, in Sherewodde is not scant:
For the soul-ravishing delicious sound
Of instrumental music, we have found
The winged choristers, with divers notes,
Sent from their quaint recording pretty throats,
On every branch that compasseth our bower:
Without command, contenting us each hour.
For Arras hangings, and rich Tapestry,
We have sweet natures best embroidery.
For thy steel glass, wherein thou wontest to look,
Thy Crystal eyes, gaze in a Crystal brooke.
At Court, a flower or two did deck thy head:
Now with whole garlands is it circled.
For what in wealth we want, we have in flowers,
And what we lose in halls, we find in bowers.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Marian hath all, sweet Robert, having thee,
And guesses thee as rich, in having me.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I am indeed:
For having thee, what comfort can I need?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Go in, go in.
To part such true love Robin, it were sin.

body.stage: Exeunt. Enter Prior, sir Doncaster, Frier Tucke.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: To take his body, by the blessed Rood,
It would do me more, than any other, good.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: O it is an unthrift, still the Churchmens foe,
An ill end will betide him, that I know.
It was he that urged the king to seize the clergy,
When to the holy land he took his journey:
And he it is that rescued those two thieves,
Scarlet and Scathlocke; that so many grieves
To Churchmen did: and now they say,
He keeps in Sherewod, and himself doth play
The lawless Rener: hear you, my Lord Prior,
He must be taken, or it will be wrong.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Aye, and he shall be too.

sp.speaker: Tuc.
sp.l: Aye, Aye; soon said: But ere he be, many will lie dead:
Except it be by sleight.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: Aye there, there, Friar.

sp.speaker: Tuck.
sp.l: Give me my Lord your execution.
The widow Scarlets daughter, lovely Iinny,
Loves, and is beloved of Much the millers son,
If I can get the girl to go with me,
Disguised in habit, like a Pedlar's mort,
I will serve this Execution, on my life,
And single out a time alone to take
Robin, that often careless walks alone.
Why? answer not, remember what I said,
Yonder I see comes Iinny, that fair maid:
If we agree, then back me soon with aid.

sp.speaker: Prior.
sp.l: Tuck if thou do it,

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: Pray you do not talk.
As we were strangers, let us careless walk.

sp.speaker: Iin.
sp.l: Now to the green wood wend I, god me speed.

sp.speaker: Tuck.
sp.l: Amen fair maid, and send thee, in thy need,
Much, that is born to do thee much good deeds.

sp.speaker: Iin.
sp.l: Are you there Friar? nay then i'faith we have it.

sp.speaker: Tuck.
sp.l: What wench? my love?

sp.speaker: Iin.
sp.l: I, give it me when I crave it.

sp.speaker: Tuck.
sp.l: Unasked I offer, pre thee sweet girl take it.

sp.speaker: Iin.
sp.l: Gifts stink with proffer, foh Friar, I forsake it.

sp.speaker: Tuck.
sp.l: I will be kind.

sp.speaker: Iin.
sp.l: Will not your kindness kill her?

sp.speaker: Tuck.
sp.l: With love?

sp.speaker: Iin.
sp.l: You cog.

sp.speaker: Tuck.
sp.l: Tut girl I am no miller: hear in your ear.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: The Friar courts her.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Tush, let him alone,
He is our Ladies Chaplain, but serves Ione.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: Then, from the Friars fault perchance, it may be
The proverb grew, Joan is taken for my Lady.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Peace good sir Doncaster, list to the end.

sp.speaker: Iin.
sp.l: But mean ye faith and troth, shall I go away?

sp.speaker: Tuck.
sp.l: Upon my faith, I do intend good faith.

sp.speaker: Iin.
sp.l: And shall I have the pins and laces too,
If I bear a Pedlar's pack with you?

sp.speaker: Tuck.
sp.l: As I am holy Friar, Iinny thou shalt.

sp.speaker: Iin.
sp.l: Well, there is my hand, see Friar you do not halt.

sp.speaker: Tuck.
sp.l: Go but before into the miry mead,
And keep the path that doth to Farnsfield lead:
I will into Suthwell, and buy all the knacks,
That shall fit both of us for Pedlar's packs.

sp.speaker: Iin.
sp.l: Who be they two that yonder walk, I prey?

sp.speaker: Tuck.
sp.l: Iinny, I know not, be they what they may,
I care not for them, pre thee do dot stay:
But make some speed, that we were gone away.

sp.speaker: Iin.
sp.l: Well Friar, I trust you that we go to Sherewod.

sp.speaker: Tuck.
sp.l: Aye by my beads, and unto Robin Hood.

sp.speaker: Iin.
sp.l: Make speed good Friar.

sp.speaker: Tuck.
sp.l: Iinny, do not fear.
Lord Prior, now you hear
As much as I; get me two Pedlar's packs,
Points, laces, looking glasses, pins and knacks:
And let sir Doncaster with some wight lads,
Follow us close: and ere these forty hours,
Upon my life, earl Robert shall be ours.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Thou shalt have anything, my dearest Friar,
And in amends, I will make thee my subprior.
Come good sir Doncaster, and if we thrive,
We will frolic with the Nuns of Leeds believe.

body.stage:
Exeunt.
Enter Fitzwater, like an olde man.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Well did he write, and mickle did he know,
That said this worlds felicity was woe,
Which greatest states can hardly undergo.
Whilom Fitzwater in fair Englands Court,
Possessed felicity and happy state:
And in his hall blithe fortune kept her sport:
Which glee, one hour of woe did ruinate.
Fitzwater once had castles, towns, and towers,
Fair gardens, orchards, and delightful bowers:
But now nor garden, orchard, town, nor tower
Hath poor Fitzwater left within his power.
Only wide walks are left me in the world,
Which these stiff limbs will hardly let me tread:
And when I sleep, heavens glorious canopy
Me and my mossy couch doth over-spread.
Of this, injurious Iohn cannot bereave me,
The air and earth he (while I live) must leave me.
But from the English air and earth, poor man,
His tyranny hath ruthless thee exiled:
Yet ere I leave it, I will do what I can,
To see Matilda, my fair luckless child:
sp.stage: Curtaines open, Robin Hoode sleepes on a greene banke, and Marian strewing flowers on him.
sp.l: And in good time, see where my comfort stands,
And by her lies dejected Huntington.
Look how my flower holds flowers in her hands,
And flings those sweets, upon my sleeping son.
I will close mine eyes as if I wanted sight,
That I may see the end of their delight.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What aged man art thou? or by what chance,
Camest thou thus far into the wailess wood?

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Widow or wife, or maiden if thou be,
Lend me thy hand: thou seest I cannot see.
Blessing betide thee, little feelest thou want:
With me, good child, food is both hard and scant.
These smooth even veins, assure me he is kind,
What ever he be, my girl, that thee doth find.
I poor and old am reft of all earths good,
And desperately am crept into this wood,
To seek the poor man's patron, Robin Hood.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And thou art welcome, welcome aged man,
I ten times welcome, to maid Marian.
Sit down old father, sit and call me daughter.
O God, how like he looks to old Fitzwater!

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Is my Matilda called maid Marian?
I wonder why her name is changed thus.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Here is wine to cheer thy heart: drink aged man.
There is venison and a knife, here is manchet fine:
Drink good old man, I pre you drink more wine.
My Robin stirs, I must sing him asleep.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Nay, you have waked me Marian with your talk.
What man is that, is come within our walk?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: An aged man, a silly sightless man,
Near pined with hunger: see how fast he eats.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Much good may it do him. Never is good meat
Ill spent on such a stomach. Father proface:
To Robin Hood thou art a welcome man.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: I thank you master. Are you Robin Hood?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Father, I am.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: God give your soul much good,
For this good meat maid Marian hath given me.
But hear you master, can you tell me news,
Where fair Matilda is, Fitzwaters daughter.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Why? here she is, this Marian is she.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Why did she change her name?

sp.speaker: Rob-
sp.l: What is that to thee?

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Yes, I could weep for grief that it is so:
But that my tears are all dried up with woe.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Why? she is called maid Marian, honest friend,
Because she lives a spotless maiden life:
And shall, till Robins outlaw life have end,
That he may lawfully take her to wife;
Which, if king Richard come, will not be long:
For, in his hand is power to right our wrong.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: If it be thus, I joy in her names change,
So pure love in these times is very strange.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Robin, I think it is my aged father.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Tell me old man, tell me in courtesy.
Are you no other than you seem to be?

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: I am a wretched aged man, you see:
If you will do me aught for charity,
Further than this, sweet, do not question me.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: You shall have your desire, but what be these?

body.stage: Enter Frier Tucke, and Iinny, like Pedlers, singing.

sp.l: What lack ye? what lack ye? what is it ye will buy?
Any points, pins, or laces, any laces, points or pins?
Fine gloves, fine glasses, any busks, or masks?
Or any other pretty things?
Come cheap for love, or buy for money.
Any cony cony skins,
For laces, points, or pins? fair maids come choose or buy.
I have pretty potting sticks,
And many other tricks, come choose for love, or buy
for money.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Peddler, I pre thee set thy pack down here:
Marian shall buy, if thou be not too dear.

sp.speaker: Tuck.
sp.l: Iinny, unto thy mistress show thy pack,
Master for you I have a pretty knack:
From far I brought it, please you see the same.

body.stage: Enter Frier like a Pedler, and Iinny, sir Doncaster, and others weaponed.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Sir Doncaster, are not we Pedlar-like?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: Yes, passing fit, and yonder is the bower:
I doubt not we shall have him in our power.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: You and your company were best stand close,

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: What shall the watchword be to bring us forth?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Take it I pray, though it be much more worth.
When I speak that aloud, be sure I serve
The execution presently on him.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: Friar, look to it.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Now Iinny to your song.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Peddler, what pretty toys have you to sell?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Iinny, unto our mistress show your ware.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Come in good woman.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Master, look here, and God give care,
sp.p: So mote I thee, to her and me, if ever we, Robin to thee, that art so free, mean treachery.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: On Peddler to thy pack,
If thou love me, my love thou shalt not lack.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Master, in brief, there is a thief, that seeks your grief, God send relief, to you in need: for a foul deed, if not with speed, you take good heed, there is decreed. In yonder brake, there lies a snake, that means to take, out of this wood, the yeoman good, called Robin Hood.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Peddler, I pre thee be more plain: what brake? what snake? what trap? what train?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Robin, I am a holy Friar, sent by the Prior, who did me hire, for to conspire thy endless woe, and overthrow: but thou shalt know, I am the man, whom little Iohn, from Notingham, desired to be, a clarke to thee; for he to me, said thou wert free, and I did see, thy honesty; from gallow tree, when thou didst free Scathlocke and Scarlet certain.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Why then it seems that thou art Friar Tuck.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Master, I am,

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I pray thee friar say,
What treachery is meant to me this day?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: First wind your horn; then draw your sword:
For I have given a friars word,
To take your body prisoner:
And yield you to sir Doncaster,
The envious Priest of Hothersfield:
Whose power your bushy wood doth shield:
But I will die, ere you shall yield.
And sith your yeomen do appear,
I will give the watchword without fear:
Take it I pray thee, though it be more worth.

body.stage: Rushe in Doncaster with his crue.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: Smite down, lay hold on outlawed Huntington.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Soft hot spurred priest, it is not so quickly done.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: Now out alas, the friar and the maid
Have, to false thieves, sir Doncaster betrayed.

body.stage: Enter Iohn crowned, Queene Elianor, Chester, Salsbury, Lord Prior, sit downe all. Warman stands.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: As Gods Vicegerent, Iohn ascends this throne,
His head impaled with Englands Diadem,
And in his hand the awful rod of rule,
Giving the humble, place of excellence,
And to the low earth, casting down the proud.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Such upright rule, is in each Realm allowed.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Chester, you once were Elies open friend,
And yet are doubtful whether he deserve
A public trial for his private wrongs.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: I still am doubtful, whether it be fit
To punish private faults with public shame,
In such a person as Lord Ely is.

sp.speaker: Prior.
sp.l: Yes Honourable Chester, more it fits
To make apparent, sins of mighty men,
And on their persons sharply to correct
A little fault, a very small defect;
Than on the poor, to practise chastisement.
For if a poor man die, or suffer shame,
Only the poor and vile respect the same:
But if the mighty fall, fear then besets
The proud hearts of the mighty ones, his mates:
They think the world is garnished with nets,
And traps ordained to entrap their states,
Which fear, in them, begets a fear of ill,
And makes them good, contrary to their will.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Your Lordship hath said right: Lord Salsbury,
Is not your mind as ours, concerning Ely?

sp.speaker: Sals.
sp.l: I judge him worthy of reproof and shame.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Warman, bring forth your prisoner, Ely the Chancellor,
And with him, bring the seal that he detains.
Warman why goest thou not?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Be good to me my Lord.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: What hast thou done?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Speak for me my Lord Prior.
All my good Lords, entreat his Grace for me.
Ely, my Lord

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Why? where is Ely Warman?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Fled today, this misty morning he is fled away.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: O Iudas, whom nor friend, nor foe may trust,
Thinkst thou with tears and plaints to answer this?
Do I not know thy heart? do not I know,
That bribes have purchased Ely this escape?
Never make antic faces, never bend,
