With fained humbles, thy still crouching knee:
But with fixed eyes, unto thy doom attend.
Villain, I will plague thee for abusing me:
Go hence, and henceforth never set thy foot
In house or field, thou didst this day possess.
Mark what I say, advise thee to look to it,
Or else be sure thou diest remediless.
Nor from those houses see that thou receive
So much as shall sustain thee for an hour:
But as thou art, go where thou canst get friends,
And he that feeds thee, be mine enemy.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: O my good Lord.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Thou thy good Lord betrayedst,
And all the world for money thou wilt sell.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: What says the Queen?

sp.speaker: Qu,
sp.l: Why thus I say:
Betray thy master, thou wilt all betray.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: My Lords, of Chester and of Salsbury?

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Speak not to us, all traitors we defy.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Good my Lord Prior.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Alas, what can I do?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Then I defy the world: yet I desire
Your Grace would read this supplication.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: I thought as much: but Warman dost thou think
There is one moving line to mercy here?
I tell thee no; therefore away, away:
A shameful death follows thy longer stay.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: O poor poor man:
Of miserable, miserablest wretch I am.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Confusion be thy guide: a baser slave
Earth cannot bear, plagues follow him I crave.
Can any tell me if my Lord of Yorke
Be able to sit up.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: The Archbishop's Grace
Was reasonable well even now, good son.

sp.speaker: Sals.
sp.l: And he desired me that I should desire
Your Majesty to send unto his Grace,
If any matter did import his presence.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: We will ourselves step in and visit him.
Mother, and my good Lords, will you attend us?

sp.speaker: Prior.
sp.l: I gladly will attend your Majesty.

sp.speaker: Ihon.
sp.l: Now good Lord help us:
When I said good Lords,
I meant not you Lord Prior: Lord I know you are:
But good, God knows, you never mean to be.

sp.speaker: Prior.
sp.l: Iohn is incensed, and very much I doubt
That villain Warman hath accused me,
About the scape of Ely: well, suppose he have:
Whats that to me? I am a Clergy man,
And all his power, if he all extend,
Cannot prevail against my holy order;
But the Archbishop's Grace is now his friend,
And may perchance attempt to do me ill.
What news with you sir?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Even heavy news my Lord: for the light fire
Falling, in manner of a fire Drake,
Upon a barn of yours, hath burnt six barnes,
And not a strike of corn reserved from dust.
No hand could save it, yet ten thousand hands,
Laboured their best, though none for love of you:
For every tongue with bitter cursing band,
Your Lordship as the viper of the land.

sp.speaker: Prior.
sp.l: What meant the villains?

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: Thus and thus they cried;
Upon this churl, this hoarder up of corn,
This spoiler of the Earl of Huntington,
This lust-defiled, merciless false Prior,
Heaven reigneth vengeance down in shape of fire.
Old wives that scarce could with their crouches creep,
And little babes, that newly learned to speak,
Men masterless that thorough want did weep,
All in one voice, with a confused cry,
In execrations band you bitterly,
Plague follow plague, they cry, he hath undone
The good Lord Robert, Earl of Huntington:
And then
What then, thou villain? Get thee from my sight.
They that wish plagues, plagues will upon them light.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: What are your tidings?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: The Covent of Saint Maries are agreed,
And have elected, in your Lordships place,
Old father Ierome, who is stalled Lord Prior,
By the new Archbishop,

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Of Yorke thou meanest.
A vengeance on him, he is my hopes foe.
Gilbert de Hood late Prior of Saint Maries,
Our Sovereign Iohn commandeth thee by me,
That presently thou leave this blessed land,
Defiled with the burden of thy sin.
All thy goods temporal and spiritual,
(With free consent of Hubert Lord Yorke,
Primate of England and thy Ordinary)
He hath suspended, and vowed by heaven,
To hang thee up, if thou depart not hence,
Without delaying or more question:
And that he hath good reason for the same,
He sends this writing firmed with Warmans hand,
And comes himself: whose presence if thou stay,
I fear this Sun will see thy dying day.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: O, Warman hath betrayed me: woe is me.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Hence with that Prior, sirrah do not speak,
My eyes are full of wrath, my heart of wreak:
Let Lester come: his halt heart, I am sure,
Will check the kingly course we undertake.

body.stage:
Exeunt cum Prior.
Enter Lester, drumme and Ancient.

sp.speaker: Iho.
sp.l: Welcome from war thrice noble earl of Lester:
Unto our Court, welcome most valiant earl.

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: Your Court in England, and king Richard gone,
A king in England, and the king from home:
This sight and salutations are so strange,
That what I should, I know not how to speak,

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: What would you say? speak boldly, we entreat.

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: It is not fear, but wonder bars my speech;
I muse to see a mother and a Queen,
Two Peers, so great as Salsbury and Chester,
Sit and support proud usurpation,
And see king Richards crown, worn by earl Iohn.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: He sits as viceroy and a substitute.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: He must and shall resign when Richard comes.

sp.speaker: Sals.
sp.l: Chester, he will without your must and shall.

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: Whether he will or no, he shall resign.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: You know your own will Lester, but not mine.

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: Tell me among ye, where is reverent Ely,
Left by our dread king, as his deputy?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Banished he is, as proud usurpers should.

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: Pride then, belike, was enemy to pride:
Ambition in yourself, his state envied.
Where is Fitzwater, that old honoured Lord?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Dishonoured and exiled, as Ely is.

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: Exiled he may be, but dishonoured never:
He was a fearless soldier, and a virtuous scholar.
But where is Huntington, that noble youth?

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: Undone by riot.

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: Ah, the greater ruth.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Lester, you question more than doth become you:
On to the purpose, why you come to us.

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: I came to Ely, and to all the State,
Sent by the king, who three times sent before,
To have his ransome brought to Austria:
And if you be elected deputy,
Do as you ought, and send the ransome money.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Lester, you see I am no deputy:
And Richards ransome if you do require,
Thus we make answer: Richard is a king,
In Cyprus, Acon, Acres, and rich Palestine:
To get those kingdoms England lent him men,
And many a million of her substance spent,
The very entrails of her womb was rent.
No plough but paid a share, no needy hand,
But from his poor estate of penury,
Unto his voyage offered more than mites,
And more, poor souls, than they had might to spare:
Yet were they joyful. For still flying news,
And lying I perceive them now to be,
Came of king Richards glorious victories,
His conquest of the Souldans, and such tales,
As blew them up with hope, when he returned,
He would have scattered gold about the streets.

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: Do Princes fight for gold? O leaden thought!
Your father knew, that honour was the aim
Kings level at: by sweet Saint Iohn I swear,
You urge me so that I cannot forbear.
What do you tell of money lent the King,
When first he went into this holy war?
As if he had extorted from the poor,
When you, the Queen, and all that hear me speak,
Know with what zeal the people gave their goods:
Old wives took silver buckles from their belts,
Young maids the gilt pins that tucked up their trains,
Children their pretty whistles from their necks,
And every man what he did most esteem,
Crying to soldiers; Wear these gifts of ours.
This proves that Richard had no need to wrong,
Or force the people, that with willing hearts
Gave more than was desired. And where you say,
You guess Richards victories but lies:
I swear he wan rich Cyprus with his sword:
And thence, more glorious than the guide of Greece,
That brought so huge a fleet to Tenedos,
He sailed along the Mediterran sea:
Where on a Sunbright morning he did meet
The warlike soldiers, well prepared fleet.
O still methinks I see king Richard stand,
In his guilt armour stained with Pagans blood,
Upon a galleys prow, like wars fierce God,
And on his crest, a Crucifix of gold.
O that days honour can be never told:
Six times six several Brigandines he boarded,
And in the greedy waves flung wounded Turkes,
And three times thrice the winged Galleys banks,
(Wherein the Souldans son was Admiral)
In his own person royal Richard smoothed,
And left no heathen hand to be upheaved
Against the Christian soldiers.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Lester, so:
Did he all this?

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: Aye by God he did,
And more than this; nay jest at it Iohn:
I swear he did, by Lesters faith he did,
And made the green sea red with Pagan blood,
Leading to Ioppa, glorious victory,
And following fear that fled unto the foe.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: All this he did, perchance all this was so.

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: Holy God help me, soldiers come away:
This carpet knight sits carping at our scars,
And jests at those most glorious well fought wars.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Lester, you are too hot: stay, go not yet:
methinks, if Richard won these victories,
The wealthy kingdoms, he hath conquered,
May better than poor England pay his ransome.
He left this Realm as a young orphan maid,
To Ely, the stepfather of this state,
That stripped the virgin to her very skin:
And Lester, had not Iohn more careful been
Than Richard, at this hour, Englad had not Englad been.
Therefore good warlike Lord, take this in brief:
We wish king Richard well,
But can send no relief.

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: O, let not my heart break with inward grief.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Yes let it Lester, it is not amiss,
That twenty such hearts break, as your heart is.

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: Are you a mother? were you Englands Queen?
Were Henry, Richard, Gefferey (your sons)
All sons, but Richard, sun of all those sons?
And can you let this little meteor,
This ignis Fatuus, this same wandering fire,
This Goblin of the night, this brand, this spark,
Seem through a lantern, greater than he is?
By heaven you do not well, by earth you do not.
Chester, nor you, nor you earl Salsbury,
Ye do not, no ye do not what ye should.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: Were this Bear loose, how he would tear our maws!

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.l: Pale death and vengeance dwell within his jaws.

sp.speaker: Sals.
sp.l: But we can muzzle him, and bind his paws,
If king Iohn say we shall, we will indeed.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Do if you can.

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: Its well thou hast some fear:
No curs, ye have no teethe to bait this Bear.
I will not bid mine ensign bearer wave
My tottered colours in this worthless air,
Which your vile breathes vilely contaminate.
Bear, thou hast been my Ancient bearer long,
And borne up Lesters Bear in foreign lands:
Yet now resign these colours to my hands.
For I am full of grief, and full of rage.
Iohn, look upon me, thus did Richard take
The coward Austrias colours in his hand,
And thus he cast them under Acon walls,
And thus he trod them underneath his feet.
Rich colours, how I wrong ye by this wrong!
But I will right ye: Bear, take them again,
And keep them ever, ever them maintain.
We shall have use for them I hope, ere long.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Darest thou attempt thus proudly in our sight?

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: What is it a subject dares, that I dare not?

sp.speaker: Sals.
sp.l: Dare subjects dare, their Sovereign being by?

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: O God, that my true Sovereign were nigh.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Lester, he is.

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: Madam, by God you lie.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: Unmannered man.

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: A plague of reverence,
Where no regard is had of excellence.
But you will quit me now; I hear your drums,
Your principality hath stirred up men,
And now ye think to muzzle up this Bear:
Still they come nearer, but are not the near.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: What drums are these?

sp.speaker: Sals.
sp.l: I think some friends of yours
Prepare a power to resist this wrong.

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: Let them prepare; for Lester is prepared,
And thus he woos his willing men to fight;
Soldiers, ye see king Richards open wrong,
Richard that led ye to the glorious East,
And made ye tread upon the blessed land,
Where he, that brought all Christians blessedness,
Was born, lived, wrought his miracles, and died,
From death arose, and then to heaven ascended;
Whose true religious faith ye have defended.
Ye fought, and Richard taught ye how to fight,
Against profane men, following Mahomet:
But if ye note, they did their kings their right,
These more than heathen, sacrilegious men,
Professing Christ, banish Christs champion hence,
Their lawful Lord, their homeborne Sovereign,
With petty quarrels, and with slight pretence.
O let me be as short as time is short,
For the armed foe is now within our sight.
Remember how against ten, one man did fight,
So hundreds against thousands, have borne head:
You are the men that ever conquered.
If multitudes oppress ye that ye die,
sell our lives, and leave them valiantly:
Courage, upon them, till we cannot stand.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Richmond is yonder.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Aye, and son, I think,
The king is not far off.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: Now heaven forfend.

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: Why smite ye not, but stand thus cowardly?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: If Richmond hurt good Lester, let him die.

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: Richmond, O pardon mine offending eye,
That took thee for a foe; welcome dear friend;
Where is my Sovereign Richard? Thou and he
Were both in Austria: Richmond, comfort me,
And tell me where he is, and how he fares.
O, for his ransome, many thousand cares
Have me afflicted.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Lester, he is come to London,
And will himself to faithless Austria,
Like a true king, his promised ransome bear.

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: At London sayst thou Richmond, is he there?
Farewell, I will not stay to tell my wrongs,
To these pale coloured, heartless, guilty Lords.
Richmond, you shall go with me, do not stay,
And I will tell you wonders by the way.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: The king did doubt you had some injury,
And therefore sent this power to rescue ye.

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: I thank his Grace. Madam adieu, adieu.
I will to your son, and leave your shade with you.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Hark how he mocks me, calling me your shade.
Chester and Salsbury, shall we gather power,
And keep what we have got?

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: And in an hour,
Be taken, iudg'd, and headed with disgrace?
Salsbury, what say you?

sp.speaker: Sals.
sp.l: My Lord, I bid your excellence adieu ---
I, to king Richard, will submit my knee,
I have good hope his Grace will pardon me.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: And Salsbury, I will go along with thee.
Farewell Queen mother, fare you well Lord Iohn.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Mother, stay you,

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Not I son, by Saint Anne,

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Will you not stay?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Go with me: I will do the best I may,
To beg my sons forgiveness of my son.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Go by yourself. By heaven it was long of you,
I rose to fall so soon. Lester and Richmonds crue,
They come to take me. Now too late I rue
My proud attempt: like falling Phaeton,
I perish from my guiding of the sun.

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: I will go back i'faith once more and see,
Whether this mock-king and the mother Queen,
And: who! here is neither Queen nor Lord.
What, king of Crickets, is there none but you?
Come off, off: this crown, this sceptre are king Richards right:
Bear thou them Richmond, thou art his true knight.
You would not send his ransome, gentle Iohn:
He is come to fetch it now. Come wily Fox,
Now you are stripped out of the Lion's case,
What, dare you look the Lion in the face?
The English Lion, that in Austria,
With his strong hand, pulled out a Lion's heart.
Good Richmond tell it me; for Gods sake do:
O, it does me good to hear his glories told.

sp.speaker: Richm.
sp.l: Lester, I saw king Richard with his fist,
Strike dead the son of Austrian Leopold,
And then I saw him, by the Dukes command,
Compassed and taken by a troop of men,
Who led king Richard to a Lion's den,
Opening the door and in a paved court,
The cowards left king Richard weaponless.
Anon comes forth the fire-eyed dreadful beast,
And with a heart-amazing voice he roared,
Opening (like hell) his iron toothed jaws,
And stretching out his fierce death-threatening paws,
I tell thee Lester, and I smile thereat,
(Though then, God knows, I had no power to smile)
I stood by treacherous Austria all the while:
Who in a gallery, with iron grates,
Staid to behold king Richard made a prey.

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: What wast, thou smilest at in Austria?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Lester, he shook, so help me God, he shook,
With very terror, at the Lion's look.

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: Ah coward: but go on what Richard did?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Richard about his right hand wound a scarf
(God quit her for it) given him by a maid,
With endless good may that good deed be paid,
And thrust that arm down the devouring throat
Of the fierce Lion, and withdrawing it,
Drew out the strong heart of the monstrous beast,
And left the senseless body on the ground.

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: O royal Richard! Richmond, look on Iohn:
Does he not quake in hearing this discourse?
Come, we will leave him Richmond, let us go,
Iohn, make suit for grace, that is your means you know.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: A mischief on that Lester: is he gone?
I were best go too, lest in some mad fit,
He turn again, and lead me prisoner.
Southward I dare not fly: fain fain I would,
To Scotland bend my course: but all the woods
Are full of Outlaws, that in Kendall green,
Follow the outlawed earl of Huntington.
Well, I will cloth myself in such a suit,
And by that means as well scape all pursuit,
As pass the danger-threatening Huntington:
For having many outlaws they will think me,
By my attire, one of their mates to be.

body.stage: Exit. Enter Scarlet, Iohn, and Frier Tucke.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Scarlet and Iohn, so God me save,
No mind unto my beads I have:
I think it be a luckless day;
For I can neither sing, nor say,
Nor have I any power to look,
On Portasse, or on Matins book.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: What is the reason, tell us Friar?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: And would ye have me be no liar.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: No: God defend that you should lie,
A Churchman be a liar? fie.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Then by this hallowed Crucifix,
The holy water, and the pyx,
It greatly at my stomach sticks,
That all this day we had no guess,
And have of meat so many a mess.

body.stage: Much bring out Ely, like a country man with a basket.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.l: Well: and ye be but a market, ye are but a market man.

sp.speaker: Ely.
sp.l: I am sure sir, I do you no hurt, do I?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: We shall have company, no doubt:
My fellow Much hath found one out.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: A fox, a fox: as I am Friar,
Much is well worthy of good hire.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Say Friar soothly knowest thou him?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: It is a wolf in a sheeps skin.
Go call our master, little Iohn,
A glad man will he be anon:
It is Ely man, the Chancellor.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Gods pity look unto him, Friar.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: What, have ye eggs to sell old fellow?

sp.speaker: Ely.
sp.p: Aye sir, some few, and those my need constrains me bear to Mansfield, That I may sell them there, to buy me bread.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Alas good man: I pre the where dost dwell?

sp.speaker: Ely.
sp.l: I dwell at Oxen sir.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: I know the town.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.l: Alas poor fellow, if thou dwell with Oxen,
Its strange they do not gore thee with their horns.

sp.speaker: Ely.
sp.l: Masters, I tell ye truly where I dwell,
And whether I am going; let me go:
Your master would be much displeased I know,
If he should hear, you hinder poor men thus.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Father, one word with you before we part.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.l: Scarlet, the Friar will make us have anger all:
Farewell, and bear me witness, though I staid him,
I staid him not:
An old fellow, and a market man?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Whoop! In your riddles Much? then we shall have it

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: What dost thou Friar? pre thee let him go.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: I pre the Scarlet let us two alone.

sp.speaker: Ely.
sp.l: Friar, I see thou knowest me, let me go:
And many a good turn I to thee will owe.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: My masters service bids me answer no:
Yet love of holy churchmen wills it so.
Well, good my Lord, I will do what I may
To let your holiness escape away:
Here comes my master, if he question you,
Answer him like a plain man, and you may pass.

sp.speaker: Ely.
sp.l: Thanks Friar.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: O, my Lord thinks me an Ass.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Friar, what honest man is there with thee?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: A silly man, good master. I will speak for you: Stand you aloof, for fear they note your face. Master in plain, it were but in vain, long to detain, with toys a with babbles, with fond fained fables: but him that you see, in so mean degree, is the Lord Ely, that helped to exile you, that oft did revile you. Though in his fall, his train be but small, and no man at all, will give him the wall, nor Lord doth him call: Yet he did ride, on Jennets pied, and knights by his side, did foot it each tide: O see the fall of pride.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Friar, enough.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: I pray sir let him go,
He is a very simple man in show,
He dwells at Oxen, and to us doth say,
To Mansfield market he doth take his way.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Friar, this is not Mansfields market day.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: What would he sell?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Eggs sir, as he says.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Scarlet, go thy ways, take in this old man,
Fill his skin with venison:
And after give him money for his eggs.

sp.speaker: Ely.
sp.l: No sir I thank yon, I have promised them
To master Bailies wife of Mansfield, all.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Nay sir you do me wrong:
No Baily, nor his wife shall have an egg.
Scarlet, I say, take his eggs, and give him money.

sp.speaker: Ely.
sp.l: Pray sir.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Tush, let him have your eggs.

sp.speaker: Ely.
sp.l: Faith I have none.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Gods pity, then he will find you soon.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Here are no eggs, nor anything but hay.
Yes by the mass, here is somewhat like a seal.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: O God, my Princes seal, fair Englands royal seal!
Tell me, thou man of death, thou wicked man,
How camest thou by this seal? wilt thou not speak?
Bring burning irons, I will make him speak.
For I do know the poor distressed Lord,
The kings Vicegerent, learned reverend Ely,
Flying the fury of ambitious Iohn,
Is murdered by this peasant. Speak vile man,
Where thou hast done thrice Honourable Ely?

sp.speaker: Ely.
sp.l: Why dost thou grace Ely with stiles of Grace,
Who thee with all his power sought to disgrace?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Belike his wisdom saw some fault in me.

sp.speaker: Ely.
sp.l: No I assure thee Honourable earl:
It was his envy, no defect of thine,
And the persuasions of the Prior of Yorke,
Which Ely now repents; see Huntington,
Ely himself, and pity him, good son.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Alas for woe, alack that so great state
The malice of this world should ruinate.
Come in great Lord, sit down and take thy ease,
Receive the seal and pardon my offence,
With me you shall be safe and if you please,
Till Richard come, from all men's violence:
Aged Fitzwater, banished by Iohn,
And his fair daughter shall con verse with you:
I and my men that me attend upon,
Shall give you all that is to Honour due.
Will you accept my service, noble Lord?

sp.speaker: Ely.
sp.l: Thy kindness drives me to such inward shame,
That for my life, I no reply can frame.
Go, I will follow, blessed myast thou be,
That thus relievest thy foes in misery.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Skelton, a word or two beside the play.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Now sir Iohn Eltam, what is it you would say?

sp.speaker: Ihon.
sp.l: Methinks I see no jests of Robin Hood,
No merry Morices of Friar Tuck,
No pleasant skippings up and down the wood,
No hunting songs, no coursing of the Buck:
Pray God this Play of ours may have good luck,
And the kings Majesty mislike it not.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: And if he do, what can we do to that?
I promised him a Play of Robin Hood,
His honourable life, in merry Sherewod;
His Majesty himself surveyed the plot,
And bad me boldly write it, it was good.
For merry jests, they have been shown before,
As how the Friar fell into the Well,
For love of Iinny that fair bonny bell:
How Greeneleafe robbed the Shrieve of Notingham,
And other mirthful matter, full of game.
Our play expresses noble Roberts wrong,
His mild forgetting treacherous injury:
The Abbots malice, raked in cinders long,
Breaks out at last with Robins Tragedy.
If these that hear the history rehearsed,
Condemn my Play when it begins to spring,
I will let it wither while it is a bud,
And never show the flower to the King.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: One thing beside; you fall into your vain,
Of ribble rabble rimes, Skeltonicall,
So oft, and stand so long, that yon offend.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: It is a fault I hardly can amend
O how I champ my tongue to talk these terms,
I do forget oft times my Friars part:
But pull me by the sleeve when I exceed,
And you shall see me mend that fault indeed.
Wherefore still sit you, doth Skelton entreat you,
While he facetè will briefly repeat you, the history all,
And tale tragical, by whose treachery, and base injury,
Robin the good, called Robin Hood, died in Sherewodde:
Which till you see, be ruled by me, sit patiently, and give a plaudit, if anything please ye.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Banished from all, of all am I bereft,
No more than what I wear, unto me left,
O wretched, wretched grief, desertful fall:
Striving to get all, I am reft of all:
Yet if I could a while myself relieve,
Till Ely be in some place settled,
A double restitution should I get,
And these sharpe sorrows that have joy suppressed,
Should turn to joy with double interest.
And in good time, here comes my cousin Warman,
Whom I have often pleasured in my time:
His house at Bingham I bestowed on him:
And therefore doubt not, he will give me house-room.
Good even good cousin.

sp.speaker: Cos.
sp.l: O cousin Warman, what good news with you?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Whether so far a foot walk you in Sherewod?

sp.speaker: Cos.
sp.l: I came from Rotheram, and by hither Farnsfield
My horse did tire, and I walked home a-foot.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: I do beseech you cousin at some friends,
Or at your own house for a week or two,
Give me some succour.

sp.speaker: Cos.
sp.l: Ha? succour say you?
No sir: I heard at Mansfield how the matter stands,
How you have justly lost your goods and lands,
And that the Princes indignation
Will fall on any that relieves your state.
Away from me, your treacheries I hate.
You when your noble master was undone
(That honourable minded Huntington )
Who forwarder than you, all to distrain?
And as a wolf that chaseth on the plain,
The harmless hind: so wolf-like you pursued
Him and his servants: vile ingratitude,
Damned Iudaisme, false wrong, abhorred treachery,
Impious wickedness, wicked impiety.
Out, out upon thee, foh, I spit at thee.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Good cousin.

sp.speaker: Cos.
sp.l: Away, I will spurn thee if thou follow me.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: O just heaven, how thou plaguest iniquity!
All that he has, my hand on him bestowed:
My master gave me all I ever owed:
My master I abused in his distress:
In mine, my kinsman leaves me comfortless.
sp.stage: Enter Iayler of Notingham, leading a dog.
sp.l: Here comes another, one that yesterday
Was at my service, came when I did call,
And him I made Jailer of Notingham,
Perchance some pity dwells within the man.
Jailer, well met, dost thou not know me man?

sp.speaker: Iay.
sp.l: Yes, thou art Warman, every knave knows thee.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Thou knowest I was thy master yesterday.

sp.speaker: Iay.
sp.l: Aye, but it is not as it was, farewell, go by.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Good George relieve my bitter misery.

sp.speaker: Iay.
sp.l: By this flesh and blood I will not.
No if I do, the devil take me quick.
I have no money: beggar balk the way.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: I do not ask thee money.

sp.speaker: Iay.
sp.l: Wouldst have meat?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Would God I had a little bread to eat.

sp.speaker: Iay.
sp.l: Soft, let me feele my bag. O hear is meat,
That I put up at Redford for my dog,
I care not greatly if I give him this.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: I pre thee do?
Yet let me search my conscience for it first:
My dog is my servant, faithful, trusty, true:
But Warman was a traitor to his Lord,
A reprobate, a rascal, and a Jew,
Worser than dogs, of men to be abhorred.
Starve therefore Warman, dog receive thy due;
Follow me not, least I belabour you,
You half faced groat, you thick-cheeked chittiface,
You Iudas, villain, you that have undone
The honourable, Robert, earl of Huntington.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Worse than a dog, the villain me respects,
His dog he feeds, me in my need rejects.
What shall I do? yonder I see a shed,
A little cottage, where a woman dwells,
Whose husband I from death delivered:
If she deny me, then I faint and die.
Ho goodwife Tomson?

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: What a noise is there?
A foul shame on ye: is it you that knocked?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: What, do you know me then?

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: Whoop, who knows not you?
The beggared banished shrieve of Notingham,
You that betrayed your master, is it not you?
Yes, a shame on you: and forsooth ye come,
To have some succour here, because you saved,
My unthrift husband from the gallow tree.
A pox upon ye both: would both for me,
Were hanged together; but soft, let me see:
The man looks faint: feelest thou indeed distress?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: O do not mock me in my heaviness.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: Indeed I do not: well I have within,
A caudle made, I will go fetch it him.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: O blessed woman, comfortable word:
Be quiet entrails, you shall be relieved:

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: Here Warman, put this hempen caudle over thy head:
See downward, yonder is thy masters walk,
And like a Iudas, on some rotten tree,
Hang up this rotten trunk of misery:
That goers by, thy wretched end may see.
Stirrest thou not villain? get thee from my door:
A plague upon thee, haste and hang thyself,
Run rogue away: it is thou that hast undone
Thy noble master, earl of Huntington.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Good counsel, and good comfort by my faith.
Three Doctors are of one opinion,
That Warman must make speed to hang himself:
The last hath given a caudle comfortable,
That to recure my griefs is strong and able:
I will take her medicine, and I will choose this way,
Wherein she saith my master hath his walk:
There will I offer life for treachery,
And hang, a wonder to all goers by.
But soft what sound harmonious is this?
What birds are these, that sing so cheerfully,
As if they did salute the flowering spring?
Fitter it were, with tunes more dolefully
They shrieked out sorrow; than thus cheerily sing,
I will go seek sad desperations cell:
This is not it, for here are green-leafed trees.
Ah for one winter-bitten bared bough,
Whereon, a wretched life, a wretch would leese.
O here is one: thrice blessed be this tree,
If a man cursed, may a blessing give
But out alas, yonder comes one to me,
To hinder death, when I detest to live.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: What woeful voice hear I within this wood?
What wretch is there complains of wretchedness?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: A man, old man, bereaved of all earths good,
And desperately seeks death in this distress.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Seek not for that which will be here too soon,
At least if thou be guilty of ill deeds.
Where art thou son? come and nearer sit,
Hear wholesome counsel, against unhallowed thoughts.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: The man is blind. Muffle the eye of day,
Ye gloomy clouds (and darker than my deeds,
That darker be than pitchy sable night)
Muster together on these high topped trees,
That not a spark of light thorough their sprays,
May hinder what I mean to execute.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: What dost thou mutter? hear me woeful man.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: God morrow father.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Welcome lovely maid,
And in good time, I trust you hither come:
Look if you see not a distressful man,
That to himself intendeth violence:
One such even now was here and is not far:
Seek I beseech you, save him if you may.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Alas here is, here is a man enraged,
Fastening a halter on a withered bough,
And stares upon me, with such frighted looks,
As I am fearful of his sharpe aspect.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: What meanest thou wretch? say, what is it thou wilt do.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: As Iudas did, so I intend to do.
For I have done already as he did:
His master he betrayed: so I have mine.
Fair mistress look not on me with your blessed eyne.
From them as from some excellence divine,
Sparkles sharpe judgment, and commands with speed
Fair, fare you well: foul fortune is my fate:
As all betrayers, I die desperate.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Soft sir, go Marian call in Robin Hood:
It is Warman woman, that was once his steward.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Alas, although it be, yet save his life:
I will send help unto you presently.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Nay Warman stay, thou shalt have thy will.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Art thou a blind man, and canst see my shame?
To hinder treachers, God restoreth sight,
And giveth infants tongues to cry aloud,
A woeful woe against the treacherous.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Hold, hold, hold. I hear say, my fellow Warman is about to hang himself, and I make some speed to save him a labour. O good master Justice Shrive, have you execution in hand, and is there such a murrain among thieves and hangmen, that you play two parts in one? For old acquaintance, I will play one part: The knot under the ear, the knitting to the tree: Good master Warman, leave that work for me.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Dispatch me Much, and I will pray for thee.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.l: Nay keep your prayers, nobody sees us.

body.stage: He takes the rope, and offers to clime.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: Down sirrah, down: whether a knaves name clime you?

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: A plague on ye for a blind sinksanker: would I were your match: you are much blind i'faith, can hit so right.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: What master Warman, are ye come to yield
A true account for your false stewardship?

sp.speaker: Scath.
sp.l: Much, if thou meanest to get a hundred pound,
Present us to the shrieve of Notingham.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.l: Mass, I think there was such a proclamation.
Come my small fellow Iohn,
You shall have half, and therefore bring in one.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: No, my big fellow, honest master Much.
Take all unto yourself, I will be no half.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.l: Then stand, you shall be the two thieves, and
I will be the presenter.
O master Shrieve of Notingham,
When ears unto my tidings came
sp.p: (I will speak in prose, I miss this verse vilely) that Scathlock and Scarlet were arrested by Robin Hood my master, and little Iohn my fellow, and I Much his servant, and taken from you master Shrieve, being well forward in the hanging way, wherein ye now are (and God keep ye in the same) and also that you master Shrieve would give any man in town, city, or country, a hundred pound of lawful arrant money of Englande, that would bring the same two thieves, being these two: now I, the said Much, challenge of you the said Shrieve, bringing them, the same money.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Faith, he cannot pay thee, Much.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Aye, but while this end is in my hand, and that about his neck, he is bound to it.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Mock on, mock on: make me your jesting game,
I do deserve much more than this small shame.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Disconsolate and poor dejected man,
Cast from thy neck that shameful sign of death,
And live for me, if thou amend thy life,
As much in favour as thou ever didst.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: O worse than any death,
When a man, wronged, his wronger pitieth.

sp.speaker: Ely.
sp.l: Warman, be comforted, rise and amend.
On my word Robin Hood will be thy friend.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I will indeed: go in, heart-broken man,
Father Fitzwater, pray you lead him in:
Kind Marian, with sweet comforts comfort him,
And my tall yeomen, as you me affect,
Upbraid him not with his forepassed life.
Warman, go in, go in and comfort thee.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: O God requite your Honours courtesy.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Scathlocke or Scarlet, help us some of ye.

body.stage: Exeunt Warman, Marian, Fitzwater, Scathlock, Scarlet, Much. Enter Frier Tucke> in his trusse, without his weede.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Iesu benedicite, pity on pity, mercy on mercy, misery on misery; O such a sight, as by this light, doth me affright.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Tell us the matter, pre thee holy Friar.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Sir Doncaster the Priest, and the proud Prior
Are stripped and wounded in the way to Bawtrey,
And if there go not speedy remedy,
They will die, they will die in this extremity.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Alas, direct us to that wretched place:
I love mine uncle, though he hateth me.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: My weed I cast to keep them from the cold,
And Iinny gentle girl tore all her smock,
The bloody issue of their wounds to stop.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Will you go with us, my good Lord of Ely?

sp.speaker: Ely.
sp.l: I will, and ever praise thy perfect charity.

body.stage: Enter Prince Iohn, solus, in greene, bowe and arrowes.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Why this is somewhat like, now may I sing,
As did the Wakefield Pinder in his note;
At Michaelmas cometh my covenant out,
My master gives me my fee:
Then Robin I will wear thy Kendall green,
And wend to the greenewodde with thee.
But for a name now, Iohn it must not be,
Already little Iohn on him attends.
Greeneleafe? Nay surely there is such a one already:
Well, I will be Wodnet, hap what happen may.
Here comes a green cote (good luck be my guide)
Some sudden shift might help me to provide.

sp.speaker: Scath.
sp.l: What fellow William, did you meet our master?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: I did not meet him yet my honest friend.

sp.speaker: Scath.
sp.l: My honest friend? why, what a term is here?
My name is Scathlocke, man, and if thou be
No other than thy garments show to me,
Thou art my fellow, though I know thee not.
What is thy name? when wert thou entertained?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: My name is Woodnet, and this very day,
My noble master, earl of Huntington,
Did give me both my fee and livery.

sp.speaker: Scath.
sp.l: Your noble master, earl of Huntington?
I will lay a crown you are a counterfeit,
And that you know, lacks money of a Noble.
Did you receive your livery and fee,
And never heard our orders read unto you?
What was the oath was given you by the Friar?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Who? Friar Tuck?

sp.speaker: Scath.
sp.l: I do not play the liar:
For he comes here himself to shrive.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Scathlock farewell, I will away.

sp.speaker: Scath.
sp.l: See you this arrow? it says nay.
Through both your sides shall fly this feather,
If presently you come not hither.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Now heavens true liberality
Fall ever for his charity,
Upon the head of Robin Hood,
That to his very foes doth good.
Lord God, how he laments the Prior,
And bathes his wounds against the fire!
Fair Marian, God requite it her,
Doth even as much for Doncaster,
Whom newly she hath lain in bed,
To rest his weary wounded head.

sp.speaker: Scath.
sp.l: Ho Friar Tuck, know you this mate?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Whats he?

sp.speaker: Scath.
sp.l: He saith my master late,
Gave him his fee and livery.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: It is a leasing, credit me.
How chance sir then you were not sworn?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: What mean this groom and losel Friar,
So strictly matters to inquire?
Had I a sword and buckler here,
You should abye these questions dear.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Sayst thou me so lad? lend him thine,
For in this bush here lieth mine:
Now will I try this new-come guest.

sp.speaker: Scath.
sp.l: I am his first man, Friar Tuck,
And if I fail and have no luck,
Then thou with him shalt have a pluck.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Be it so Scathlocke: hold thee lad,
No better weapons can be had:
The dew doth them a little rust:
But hear ye, they are tools of trust.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Gramercy Friar for this gift,
And if thou come unto my shrift,
I will make thee call those fellows fools
That on their foes bestow such tools.

sp.speaker: Scath.
sp.l: Come let us to it.

body.stage: Fight, and the Frier lookes on.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: The youth is deliver and light,
He presseth Scathlocke with his might:
Now by my beads to do him right,
I think he be some tried knight.

sp.speaker: Scath.
sp.l: Stay, let us breath.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: I will not stay:
If you leave, Friar, come away.

sp.speaker: Scath.
sp.l: I pre the Friar hold him play.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Friar Tuck will do the best he may.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Why, what a noise of swords is here?
Fellows, and fight our bower so near?

sp.speaker: Scath.
sp.l: Mistress, he is no man of yours,
That fights so fast with Friar Tuck:
But on my word he is a man,
As good for strength as any can.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Indeed he is more than common men can be,
In his high heart there dwells the blood of kings.
Go call my Robin, Scathlock: it is Prince Iohn.

sp.speaker: Scath.
sp.l: Mistress I will, I pray part the fray.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I pre thee go, I will do what I may.
Friar I charge thee hold thy hand.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Nay yonker, to your tackling stand.
What all amort, will you not fight?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: I yield, unconquered by thy might:
But by Matildas glorious sight.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Mistress, he knows you: what is he?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Like to amazing wonder she appears,
And from her eye, flies love unto my heart,
Attended by suspicious thoughts and fears,
That numb the vigour of each outward part:
Only my sight hath all satiety,
And fullness of delight, viewing her deity.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: But I have no delight in you Prince Iohn.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Is this Prince Iohn?
Give me thy hand, thou art a proper man,
And for this mornings work, by Saints above,
Be ever sure of Friar Tucks true love.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Be not offended that I touch thy shrine
Make this hand happy, let it fold in thine.

body.stage: Enter Robin Hoode, Fitzwater, Ely, Warman.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: What saucy woodman Marian stands so near?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: A woodman Robin, that would strike your deer,
With all his heart. Nay never look so strange,
You see this fickle world, is full of change:
Iohn is a ranger, man, compelled to range.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: You are young, wild Lord, and well may travel bear.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: What, my old friend Fitzwater, are you there?
And you Lord Ely? and old best betrust?
Then I perceive that to this gear we must.
A mess of my good friends, which of you four
Will purchase thanks by yielding to the king,
The body of the rash rebellious Iohn?
Will you Fitzwater?

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: No Iohn, I defy,
To stain my old hands in thy youthful blood.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: You will Lord Ely, I am sure you will.

sp.speaker: Ely.
sp.l: Be sure young man, my age means thee no ill.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: O you will have the praise, brave Robin Hood:
The lusty outlaw, Lord of this large wood,
He will lead a kings son, prisoner to a king,
And bid the brother smite the brother dead.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: My purpose you have much misconstrued:
Prince Iohn, I would not for the wide worlds wealth
Incense his Majesty: but do my best,
To mitigate his wrath, if he be moved.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Will none of you? then here is one I dare say,
That from his childhood, knows how to betray:
Warman, will not you help to hinder all you may.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: With what I have been, twit me not my Lord.
My old sins at my soul I do detest.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Then that he came this way, prince Iohn was blessed.
Forgive me Ely, pardon me Fitzwater:
And Robin, to thy hands myself I yield.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: And as my heart, from hurt I will thee shield.

sp.speaker: Mu.
sp.l: Master fly, hide ye mistress, we all shall be taken.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Why, whats the matter?

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.l: The king, the king, amp; twelve and twenty score of horses.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Peace fool. we have no cause from him to fly.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Scarlet and I were hunting on the plain.
To us came royal Richard from his train
(For a great train of his is hard at hand)
And questioned us, if we served Robin Hood:
I said we did: and then his Majesty,
Putting this massy chain about my neck,
Said what I shame to say, but joyed to hear:
Let Sarlet tell it, it befits not me.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Quoth our good king, thy name is little Iohn,
And thou hast long time served earl Huntington:
Because thou leftest him not in misery,
A hundred marks I give thee yearly fee,
And from henceforth, thou shalt a squire be.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.l: O Lord what luck had I to run away?
I should have been made a knight, or a lady sure.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Go, said the king, and to your master say,
Richard is come to call him to the court.
And with his kingly presence chase the clouds
Of grief and sorrow, that in misty shades,
Have veiled the honour of earl Huntington.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Now God preserve him, hie you back again,
And guide him, lest in by-paths he mistake.
Much, fetch a richer garment for my father:
Good Friar Tuck, I pre thee rouse thy wits.
Warman, visit mine uncle and sir Doncaster,
See if they can come forth to grace our show.
Gods pity Marian, let your Iinny wait.
Thanks my Lord Chancellor: you are well prepared,
And good Prince Iohn, since you are all in green,
Disdain not to attend on Robin Hood:
Frolic I pray, I trust to do ye good.
Welcome good uncle, welcome sir Doncaster.
Say, will ye sit, I fear ye cannot stand.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Yes, very well.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Why, cheerily cheerily then.
The trumpet, sounds, the king is now at hand:
Lords, yeomen, maids, in decent order stand.

body.stage: The trumpets sound, the while Robin places them. Enter first, bare-heade, little Iohn and Scarlet; likewise Chester, and Lester, bearing the sword and scepter; the King follow crowned, clad in green: after him Queene mother, after her Salsbury and Richmond. Scarlet and Scathlocke turne to Robin Hoode; who with all his copany kneele downe and cry.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: God save King Richard, Lord preserve your Grace.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thanks all, but chiefly, Huntington, to thee.
Arise poor earl, stand up&Htp;, my late lost son,
And on thy shoulders let me rest my arms,
That have been toiled long with heathen wars:
True pillar of my state, right Lord indeed,
Whose honour shineth in the den of need,
I am even full of joy, and full of woe;
To see thee, glad: but sad to see thee so.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: O that I could pour out my soul in prayers,
And praises for this kingly courtesy.
Do not, dread Lord, grieve at my low estate:
Never so rich, never so fortunate,
Was Huntington as now himself he finds.
And to approve it, may it please your Grace,
But to accept such presents at the hand
Of your poor servant, as he hath prepared,
You shall perceive, the Emperor of the East,
Whom you contended with at Babilon,
Had not such presents to present you with.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Art thou so rich? sweet let me see thy gifts.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: First take again this Jewel you had lost,
Aged Fitzwater, banished by Iohn.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: A gem indeed: no Prince hath such a one.
Good, good old man, as welcome unto me,
As cool fresh air, in heats extremity.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: And I as glad to kiss my Sovereigns hand,
As the wracked swimmer, when he feels the land.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Welcome Fitzwater, I am glad to see you.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.l: I thank your Grace: but let me hug these twain,
Lester and Richmond, Christ's sworn champions,
That followed Richard in his holy war.

sp.speaker: Richm.
sp.l: Noble Fitzwater, thanks, and welcome both.

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.l: O God how glad I am to see this Lord!
I cannot speak: but welcome at a word.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Next take good Ely in your royal hands,
Who fled from death, and most uncivil bands.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Robin, thy gifts exceed: Moorton my Chancellor!
In this man givest thou holiness and honour.

sp.speaker: Ely.
sp.l: Indeed he gives me, and he gave me life,
Preserving me from fierce pursuing foes,
When I too blame, had wrought him many woes:
With me he likewise did preserve this seal,
Which I surrender to your majesty.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Keep it good Ely, keep it still for me.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: The next fair Jewel that I will present
Is richer than both these, yet in the foil,
My gracious Lord, it hath a foul default:
Which if you pardon, boldly I protest,
It will in value far exceed the rest.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: That is me he means, i'faith my turn is next.
He calls me foil, i'faith I fear a foil.
Well, it is a mad Lord, this same Huntington.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Here is Prince Iohn your brother, whose revolt,
And folly in your absence, let me crave,
With his submission may be buried.
For he is now no more the man he was,
But dutiful in all respects to you.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Pray God it prove so. Well good Huntington,
For thy sake pardoned is our brother Iohn,
And welcome to us in all hearty love.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: This last I give, as tenants do their lands,
With a surrender, to receive again,
The same into their own possession:
No Marian, but Fitzwaters chaste Matilda:
The precious Jewel that poor Huntington,
Doth in this world, hold as his best esteem.
Although with one hand I surrender her,
I hold the other, as one looking still,
Richard returns her: so I hope he will.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Else God forbid: receive thy Marian back,
And never may your love be separate,
But flourish fairly to the utmost date.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Now please my king to enter Robins bower,
And take such homely welcome as he finds,
It shall be reckoned as my happiness.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: With all my heart: then as combined friends,
Go we together, here all quarrels ends.

body.stage: Exeunt. Manet Sir Iohn Eltam and Skelton.

sp.speaker: S. Ioh.
sp.l: Then Skelton here I see you will conclude.

sp.speaker: Skel.
sp.l: And reason good: have we not held too long?

sp.speaker: S. Ioh.
sp.l: No in good sadness, I dare gage my life,
His Highness will accept it very kindly.
But I assure you, he expects withal,
To see the other matters tragical,
That follow in the process of the story,
Wherein are many a sad accident,
Able to make the strictest mind relent:
I need not name the points, you know them all.
From Marians eye shall not one tear be shed?
Skelton, i'faith it is not the fashion.
The King must grieve, the Queen must take it ill:
Ely must mourn, aged Fitzwater weep,
Prince Iohn, the Lords: his yeomen must lament,
And wring their woeful hands, for Robins woe.
Then must the sick man fainting by degrees,
Speak hollow words, and yield his Marian,
Chaste maid Matilda, to her fathers hands:
And give her, with king Richards full consent,
His lands, his goods, late seized on by the Prior,
Now by the Priors treason made the kings.
Skelton, there are a many other things,
That ask long time to tell them lineally:
But ten times longer will the action be.

sp.speaker: Skel.
sp.l: Sir Iohn, i'faith I know not what to do:
And I confess that all you say is true.
Will you do one thing for me, crave the king
To see two parts: say it is a pretty thing:
I know you can do much, if you excuse me,
While Skelton lives, Sir Iohn be bold to use me.

sp.speaker: S. Ioh.
sp.l: I will persuade the king: but how can you
Persuade all these beholders to content?

sp.speaker: Skel.
sp.l: Stay sir Iohn Eltam; what to them I say,
Deliver to the king, from me, I pray.
Well judging hearers, for a while suspense
Your censures of this Play's unfinished end:
And Skelton promises for this offence,
The second part shall presently be penned:
There shall you see, as late my friend did note,
King Richards revels at earl Roberts bower,
The purposed mirth, and the performed moan,
The death of Robin, and his murderers.
For interest of your stay, this will I add,
King Richards voyage back to Austria:
The swift returned tidings of his death,
The manner of his royal funeral.
Then Iohn shall be a lawful crowned king,
But to Matilda bear unlawful love.
Aged Fitzwaters final banishment:
His piteous end, of power tears to move
From marble pillars. The Catastrophe
Shall show you fair Matildas Tragedy,
Who (shunning Iohns pursuit, became a Nun,
At Dumwod Abbey, where she constantly
Chose death to save her spotless chastity.
Take but my word, and if I fail in this,
Then let my pains be baffled with a hiss.
